{{Infobox building | name = 450 Lexington Avenue | native_name = | native_name_lang = | former_names = | alternate_names = | status = Complete | image = 450 Lexington Avenue.jpg | image_alt = | image_size = | location = 450 [[Lexington Avenue]]
[[Manhattan]], New York City | address = | location_country = United States | coordinates = {{coord|40.753268|-73.975443|display=inline,title}} | groundbreaking_date = | start_date = | completion_date = 1992 | opened_date = | inauguration_date = | demolition_date = | architect = [[Warren and Wetmore]] (Original structure)
[[Skidmore, Owings, and Merrill]] (New tower) | landlord = | owner = [[RXR Realty]] | cost = | floor_area = {{convert|910,273|sqft|m2|0}} | top_floor = | floor_count = 38 | awards = | ren_awards = | parking = | url = | embed = | embedded = | references = | map_type = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map_dot_label = | relief = | altitude = | building_type = Commercial | architectural_style = | structural_system = | ren_cost = | client = | current_tenants = | renovation_date = | height = {{convert|173|m|ft}} | architectural = | tip = | antenna_spire = | roof = | observatory = | other_dimensions = | seating_type = | seating_capacity = | elevator_count = | architecture_firm = | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | main_contractor = | designations = | ren_architect = | ren_firm = | ren_str_engineer = | ren_serv_engineer = | ren_civ_engineer = | ren_oth_designers = | ren_qty_surveyor = | rooms = | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image_caption = | map_size = | etymology = | cancelled = | topped_out = | classification = | location_city = | namesake = | est_completion = | topped_out_date = | relocated_date = | closing_date = | affiliation = | diameter = | circumference = | weight = | material = | size = | grounds_area = | developer = | engineer = | known_for = | ren_engineer = | ren_contractor = | footnotes = }} '''450 Lexington Avenue''' is a 38-story office building located on [[Lexington Avenue]] between East 44th and East 45th streets, in [[Manhattan]].{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/11/25/realestate/commercial-property-450-lexington-avenue-up-depths-neo-neo-classical-tower.html|title=Commercial Property: 450 Lexington Avenue; Up From the Depths: A Neo-Neo-Classical Tower|last=Dunlap|first=David W.|authorlink=David W. Dunlap|date=25 November 1990|work=The New York Times|accessdate=14 July 2016}} The building, which was built in 1992, is clad in Sardinian gray [[granite]] and features a repeating diamond motif that highlights the building [[setback (architecture)|setbacks]] and its crown. The tower was built within and on top of the preexisting structure of the [[Grand Central Terminal|Grand Central]] Post Office, which was designed by [[Warren and Wetmore]] and constructed from 1906 to 1909.{{cite web|url=http://www.emporis.com/buildings/115528/450-lexington-avenue-new-york-city-ny-usa|title=450 Lexington Avenue|publisher=Emporis|accessdate=14 July 2016}} It was originally developed by [[Hines Interests Limited Partnership|Hines]] after anchor tenant and original developer [[Prudential Financial]] backed out of the project.{{cite web|url=https://www.hines.com/properties/450-lexington-new-york|title=450 Lexington|publisher=Hines|accessdate=14 July 2016}} The building is currently owned by [[RXR Realty]], and was owned by [[Istithmar World]] from 2006 to 2012.{{cite web|url=http://therealdeal.com/2013/06/10/rxr-to-scoop-up-49-percent-stake-in-one-worldwide-plaza/|title=RXR to scoop up 49 percent stake in One Worldwide Plaza|last=Mauer|first=Mark|date=10 June 2013|publisher=The Real Deal|accessdate=14 July 2016}}{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/06/05/nyregion/05cnd-hotel.html|title=New Owners Plan to Bring Knickerbocker Hotel Back to Times Square|last=Bagli|first=Charles V.|date=5 June 2006|work=The New York Times|accessdate=14 July 2016}} Istithmar purchased 450 Lexington in 2006 but refinanced the property the following year for $600 million.{{Cite news|url=https://commercialobserver.com/2012/07/rxr-realty-to-buy-450-lexington-avenue-from-istithmar-world-capital/|title=RXR Realty To Buy 450 Lexington Avenue from Istithmar World Capital|last=Rosen|first=Daniel Edward|date=2012-07-11|work=|newspaper=Commercial Observer|language=|access-date=2017-01-18|via=}} Current tenants include [[Brixmor Property Group]], [[Davis Polk & Wardwell]], [[Herbert Smith Freehills]], [[Warburg Pincus]], and [[WeWork]].{{cite web|url=http://therealdeal.com/2016/03/04/wework-and-lend-lease-in-talks-for-global-office-venture-report/|title=WeWork, Lend Lease in talks for global office venture: report|last=Malesevic|first=Dusica Sue|date=3 March 2016|publisher=The Real Deal|accessdate=14 July 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{Commons category-inline}} [[Category:Commercial buildings completed in 1992]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Manhattan]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]] [[Category:Lexington Avenue]] {{Manhattan-struct-stub}}

'''Aleksandar "Aco" Đukanović''' ({{lang-cnr|Ацо Ђукановић}}) is a controversial [[Montenegro|Montenegrin]] businessman, widely considered to be one of the richest and most powerful individuals in the country, along with [[Brano Mićunović]]. [[Vesko Barović]], [[Dragan Brković]] and others from the Montenegrin [[nouveau riche]] class that emerged during the 1990s following the break-up of [[SFR Yugoslavia]]. All of Aco Đukanović's wealth and influence were achieved during his older brother [[Milo Đukanović]]'s rule in Montenegro as Prime Minister and President of the Republic (1991–2006) and currently as the ruling political party's ([[Democratic Party of Socialists of Montenegro|DPS]]) president and prime minister again (2006–present).
==Life== ===Early activities=== Aco Đukanović's early business activity during the 1990s was folk concert booking, promotion and organizing through his first company Maraton.
===2000s=== Aco Đukanović was in the news when along with Vladislav "Pajo" Jabučanin he physically attacked and beat up [[Liberal Alliance of Montenegro|LSCG]] activist Zoran "Feki" Kljajić.[http://www.b92.net/info/vesti/index.php?yyyy=2000&mm=06&dd=05&nav_category=1&nav_id=7404] The attack occurred on Sunday, June 4, 2000 at around 11:30pm in the lobby of Hotel Crna Gora in [[Podgorica]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20020909123203/http://www.medijaklub.cg.yu/zanimljivi/zanimljivi06-00/06-1.htm] Kljajić ended up with severe injuries - skull fracture on the forehead for which he underwent emergency surgery.[http://arhiva.glas-javnosti.rs/arhiva/2000/06/07/srpski/H00060601.shtm] Jabučanin and Đukanović were detained by police.[http://arhiva.glas-javnosti.rs/arhiva/2000/06/07/srpski/H00060602.shtm] The case against Đukanović dragged in the courts for years before being acquitted in December 2004 while Jabučanin got sentenced to 4 months in prison.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110722174111/http://www.pobjeda.co.me/citanje.php?datum=2004-12-10&id=49533] On appeal, the re-trial was ordered, but in 2007 on the very first session of the re-trial the court concluded that the suit against Đukanović is too old.[https://web.archive.org/web/20090810125212/http://www.monitorcg.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=742%3Abracova-vremena&catid=346%3Abroj-970&Itemid=584]
His current company Monte Nova is prominent as a Montenegrin business - according to an annual report by [[Central Bank of Montenegro|Montenegrin Central Bank]], Monte Nova is the fourth most profitable company in Montenegro (most profitable among the companies with domestic ownership) with a profit of [[euro|€]]8.1 million in year 2006.<small>[http://www.mtsmondo.com/news/vesti/story.php?vest=77288]{{dead link|date=January 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</small> In November 2006, Monte Nova acquired [[Nikšićka banka]]. Monte Nova reportedly also holds substantial influence in Elektroprivreda CG (Montenegrin hydro company) as it is trying to take over [[Pljevlja]] [[coal mine]] (accounting for 100% of Montenegro's coal production) and [[thermal power station]] (accounting for 45% of power supply within the republic).<small>[http://www.revija92.novosti.rs/code/navigate.php?Id=215]{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</small>
Đukanović also held stake in [[Crnogorska komercijalna banka]], which he sold to Hungarian [[OTP Bank]], reportedly for [[euro|€]]10 million.
In January 2007, he bought 75% stake in Montenegrin urbanism authority for [[euro|€]]2.7 million.<small>[http://www.b92.net/biz/vesti/region.php?yyyy=2007&mm=01&dd=21&nav_id=228622&fs=1]</small>
Around the same time he bought the documentation for the third [[mobile telephony|mobile operator]] licence in Montenegro but ended up not placing an official bid, and the licence went to [[Telekom Srbija]].<small>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110725141251/http://www.danas.rs/20070216/ekonomija1.html#1]</small>
==Personal== Đukanović has one daughter, born out of wedlock.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}}
==External links== *[http://www.b92.net/biz/vesti/region.php?yyyy=2007&mm=01&dd=22&nav_id=228703&fs=1 Đukanović i Barović šire poslovanje], [[B92]], January 22, 2007 *[http://www.b92.net/biz/vesti/srbija.php?yyyy=2007&mm=03&dd=30&nav_id=239290 Aco Đukanović hoće "Putnik"?], B92, March 30, 2007
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dukanovic, Aco}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Montenegrin businesspeople]] [[Category:People from Nikšić]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

{{Infobox person | name = Alice du Pont Mills | image = | imagesize = | caption = |birth_name=Alice Frances du Pont | birth_date = December 13, 1912 | birth_place = [[Wilmington, Delaware]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2002|3|13|1912|12|13}} | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = [[Middleburg, Virginia]],
[[Hobe Sound, Florida]] | education = | occupation = [[Aviator]], Racehorse owner/breeder, Philanthropist | known_for = | party = | spouse = [[James P. Mills]] | children = May Chichester, Phyllis Overton, James Paul Jr. | parents = [[A. Felix du Pont]] & Mary Chichester | relations = Siblings:
[[Alexis Felix du Pont, Jr.|Alexis Felix, Jr.]] (1905-1996)
[[Lydia Chichester du Pont|Lydia Chichester]] (1907-1958)
[[Richard Chichester du Pont|Richard Chichester]] (1911-1943) | boards = [[Planned Parenthood]], Chichester du Pont Foundation, Grayson-Jockey Club Research Foundation | honors = {{unbulleted list | Kentucky Thoroughbred Breeders' Association's Ladies' Sportsmanship Award (1970) | Virginia Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association Outstanding Owner/Breeder Award (1991) }} }} '''Alice Frances du Pont Mills''' (December 13, 1912 - March 13, 2002) was an [[United States|American]] [[aviator]], [[thoroughbred]] [[race horse]] breeder and owner, [[environmentalist]], [[philanthropist]] and a member of the prominent [[du Pont family]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/16/classified/paid-notice-deaths-mills-alice-dupont.html ''New York Times'' obituary for Alice Mills duPont] == Biography == Born in [[Wilmington, Delaware]], the daughter of [[A. Felix du Pont]] (1879–1948) and Mary Chichester (1878–1965), after graduating from [[Oldfields School]] in [[Glencoe, Maryland|Glencoe]], [[Maryland]], the wealthy Alice du Pont pursued a wide variety of interests. Like her brothers, [[Alexis Felix du Pont, Jr.|Felix]] and [[Richard C. du Pont|Richard]], she too had a passion for flying. In 1932, she was only twenty years old when she and brother Richard flew an open-cockpit plane up the [[Amazon River]]. In 1935, she married James Paul Mills (1908–1987)[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/courant/access/843627972.html?dids=843627972:843627972&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Nov+30%2C+1935&author=&pub=Hartford+Courant&desc=Miss+Alice+Du+Pont+Weds+J.+P.+Mills%2C+Broker&pqatl=google ''Hartford Courant - November 30, 1935], who shared her love of flying and with whom she had three children. Her daughter Phyllis married artist [[Jamie Wyeth]].{{cite web |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2012/writers/tim_layden/05/01/union.rags/index.html |title=The story behind Union Rags and two people's shot at Derby glory |date=May 4, 2012 |publisher=[[Sports Illustrated]] |author=Tim Layden}} Her grandson was Richard P. Mills (aka Grimnir Wotansvolk / G. Heretik, owner of the American National Socialist black metal record label and distro "Vinland Winds") who died in mysterious circumstances (drug overdose) on August 28, 2006.{{Cite web |url=http://www.gunstonhall.org/library/masonweb/p142.htm |title=Richard P. Mills- Son Of James P Mills Grandson of Alice duPont Mills-Records of Birth |access-date=2010-09-20 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100925174542/http://gunstonhall.org/library/masonweb/p142.htm#i3600%20 |archive-date=2010-09-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}[http://miva.delawareonline.com/miva/cgi-bin/miva?obits.mv+62583 Richard Paul Mills Obituaries Delaware Online] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709011140/http://miva.delawareonline.com/miva/cgi-bin/miva?obits.mv+62583 |date=2011-07-09 }} During [[World War II]], Ms du Pont Mills served as a volunteer flight instructor for [[United States military]] pilots at an airfield on [[Long Island, New York]]. With the war over, in 1946 she and her husband flew a single-engine plane from [[New York City]] to [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]].[https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/16/classified/paid-notice-deaths-mills-alice-dupont.html ''New York Times'' - March 16, 2002] The Chichester du Pont Foundation was incorporated in 1946 by Alice du Pont Mills, [[A. Felix du Pont, Jr.]], [[Lydia Chichester du Pont]], and Mary Chichester du Pont Clark. The foundation, which remains in operation, is primarily involved in supporting youth with donations made to social service organizations for the direct benefit of children. == Thoroughbred racing == In 1949, she and her husband settled on a country estate in [[Middleburg, Virginia]] where they maintained Hickory Tree Farm and Stable, a [[thoroughbred]] breeding and racing operation. Her stable won numerous [[stakes race]]s, notably in 1966 when her [[filly]] [[Glad Rags II|Glad Rags]] won a [[British Classic Races|British Classic Race]], the [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]].[http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/8600/ownerbreeder-alice-dupont-mills-dies-at-89 March 15, 2002 Bloodhorse.com article titled "''Owner/Breeder Alice duPont Mills Dies at 89''"] At the 1982 [[Keeneland Sales|Keeneland yearling sale]] she bought the [[Windfields Farm]] [[colt (horse)|colt]], [[Devil's Bag]]. Trained by [[Woody Stephens]], Devil's Bag was voted the [[Eclipse Award]] winner as [[American Champion Two-Year-Old Colt]] of 1983 and a favorite for the 1984 [[Kentucky Derby]], However, the horse had to be retired after sustaining an injury. Devil's Bag was syndicated for [[US$]]36 million as a [[Horse breeding|breeding sire]], and produced more than 40 stakes winners before his death in 2005.[https://archive.is/20120715020105/http://terryconway.net/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=183:work-of-art&catid=9:racing-history&Itemid=18 Blood-Horse magazine October 15, 2011] Through her involvement with thoroughbred horses, Alice du Pont Mills became a member of the Virginia Thoroughbred Association, Hickory Tree Farm and Stable elected a member of its Hall of Fame. She served as a Trustee of the United States Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association, was an Advisory Trustee to the [[National Museum of Racing and Hall of Fame]], and was a Director of the Grayson-Jockey Club Research Foundation. A founding member of the Marion duPont Scott Equine Medical Center in [[Leesburg, Virginia]], Alice du Pont Mills' cousin, [[Marion duPont Scott]], was a significant owner/breeder in both [[flat racing|flat]] and [[steeplechase (horse racing)|steeplechase]] racing. Involved in a number of charitable works, Alice du Pont Mills was a member of the national board of directors of Planned Parenthood. A conservationist, she was an active advocate for the preservation and careful management of the environment and of natural resources, serving as founding member of Virginia's Bull Run Conservancy and the Piedmont Environmental Council and became a Trustee of the Virginia Outdoors Foundation. Alice du Pont Mills died in Virginia in 2002. == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mills, Alice du Pont}} [[Category:1912 births]] [[Category:2002 deaths]] [[Category:American female aviators]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:American racehorse owners and breeders]] [[Category:Aviators from Delaware]] [[Category:Du Pont family|Alice du Pont Mills]] [[Category:People from Middleburg, Virginia]] [[Category:People from Hobe Sound, Florida]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox theologian | image = LutheranVespers_cropped.jpg |caption = Bonnie with her husband on the set of ''[[Vespers in Lutheranism|Lutheran Vespers]]''. | birth_name = Bonnie Lou Hagedorn | birth_date = {{Birth-date and age|October 11, 1938}} | birth_place = [[Royal, Iowa]], U.S. | tradition_movement = [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in America]] | occupation = [[Minister (Christianity)|Minister]]
[[ELCA Global Mission]], Director | main_interests = | education = [[Dana College]] [[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]] [[Doctor of Divinity|DD.Min.]] (Hon)
[[Wartburg Theological Seminary]], [[Master of Divinity|M.Div.]] [[Doctor of Divinity|D.Div.]] (Hon) | notable_ideas = | notable_works = | spouse = [[Richard A. Jensen]] | children = 3 | influences = | influenced = }} '''Bonnie Lou Jensen''' (born October 11, 1938) is an American former missionary, international relations specialist, and director of the [[ELCA Global Mission]].{{cite web |last1=Lee |first1=Albert H. |title=Bonnie Jensen to Retire as Director of ELCA Global Mission |website=www.christianpost.com/news/bonnie-jensen-to-retire-as-director-of-elca-global-mission-14196/ |publisher=www.christianpost.com |accessdate=December 14, 2014}} ==Early life and education== '''Bonnie Lou Hagedorn''' was born in [[Royal, Iowa]], and received degrees from [[Dana College]] and [[Wartburg Theological Seminary]]. She married American theologian [[Richard A. Jensen]] in 1957. Jensen moved to [[Addis Ababa, Ethiopia]], to assist with the founding of the [[Ethiopian Evangelical Church Mekane Yesus|Mekane Yesus Seminary]] in 1962. ==Career== [[File:Jensen_in_Ethiopia_in_1965.jpg|thumb|right|Jensen with her [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in America|ELCA Global Mission]] predecessor, Mark Thomsen.]] Jensen served as executive director of the former [[American Lutheran Church]] Women (ALCW), [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] from 1981 to 1987. From 1982 to 1987, Jensen and her husband, served as co-hosts of ''Reflections'', a 30-minute Christian television series. From 1993 to 1995, Jensen served as director for planning and evaluation and program director for [[Papua New Guinea]] and the [[Oceania|South Pacific]] for the [[Evangelical Lutheran Church in America]]. ===ELCA Global Mission=== Jensen became the director the ELCA Global Mission in 1995. Under her leadership in mission education, the ELCA companion synod program grew its relationships between the ELCA's 65 synods and Lutheran churches overseas. The ELCA's 10,816 congregations are organized into synods across the United States and Caribbean. Under her leadership the ELCA Global Mission had a presence in 70 countries with 300 missionaries and volunteers, 47 division staff based, with annual expenditures of $29 million. Jensen was also involved in [[Track II diplomacy]], serving on the [[Lutheran World Federation]] (LWF) in Geneva, Switzerland during the 1980s, during this time the LWF had a [[Nongovernmental organization|NGO chair]] at the [[United Nations]]. ==Personal life== In 1957, she married [[Richard A. Jensen]]. They had three children together, [[Doron Jensen|Doron]], Dodi, and Derek. ==Legacy== Jensen served on the board of [[Dana College]] and upon her retirement in 2003, she was awarded an honorary doctorate in divinity for her work in her field. She previously received an honorary doctorate from [[Wartburg Theological Seminary]] in 1997.{{cite web |last1=Brooks |first1=John |title=Rev. Bonnie L. Jensen to Retire as Director of ELCA Global Mission |website=www.elca.org/News-and-Events/4735 |publisher=elca.org |accessdate=December 14, 2014}} She is noted as the first female to take leadership role within the ELCA and was one of the earliest feminist leaders in Lutheranism. ===Honorary degrees=== {| border="1" border="1" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="width:100%; margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0; border:1px #056 solid; border-collapse:collapse;" |- ! style="background:#f5f5f5; width:20%;"| Location !! style="background:#f5f5f5; width:20%;"| Date !! style="background:#f5f5f5; width:40%;"| School !! style="background:#f5f5f5; width:20%;"| Degree |- | {{Flagu|Nebraska}} || '''May 2003''' || [[Dana College]] || [[Doctor of Divinity]] (DDiv) |- | {{Flagu|Iowa}} || '''May 1997''' || [[Wartburg Theological Seminary]] || [[Doctor of Divinity]] (DDiv) |} {{Portal|Lutheranism}} [[File:Jensen_on_the_set_of_Reflections.jpg|thumb|right|Jensen on the set of ''Reflections''.]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jensen, Bonnie Lou}} [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Wartburg Theological Seminary alumni]] [[Category:Evangelical Lutheran Church in America Christians]] [[Category:Jensen family]] [[Category:Dana College alumni]] [[Category:People from Clay County, Iowa]]

{{Admiralty law}}
A '''charterparty''' (sometimes '''charter-party''') is a maritime contract between a [[shipowner]] and a "charterer" for the hire of either a ship for the carriage of passengers or cargo, or a yacht for pleasure purposes.
The name "charterparty" is an [[anglicisation]] the [[French language|French]] ''charte partie'', or "split paper", i.e. a document written in duplicate so that each party retains half.<ref name="EB1911">{{Cite EB1911|wstitle=Charter-party|volume=5|pages=953}}</ref><ref>The [[Latin]] term ''charta partita'' is a [[back-formation]], and not a true etymological source.</ref>
==Types of charterparty== {{main|Chartering (shipping)}} There are three main types of charterparty: '''time, voyage''' and '''demise and another ''': * In a '''[[demise charter|demise]] (or bareboat) charter''', the charterer takes responsibility for the crewing and maintenance of the ship during the time of the charter. He assumes the legal responsibilities of the owner, and is known as a disponent owner.{{citation needed|date=January 2018}} * In a '''[[time charter]]''', the vessel is hired for a specific amount of time. The shipowner manages the vessel but the charterer gives orders for the employment of the vessel, and may sub-charter the vessel on a time charter or voyage charter basis. * In a '''[[voyage charter]]''', the charterer hires the vessel for a single voyage, but the shipowner provides the master, crew, [[bunkers]] and supplies.<ref>[http://www.maritimeknowhow.com/English/Know-How/Chartering/types_of_contracts_of_affreightment/voyage_charter.html Maritimeknowhow website: voyage charter] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714034807/http://www.maritimeknowhow.com/English/Know-How/Chartering/types_of_contracts_of_affreightment/voyage_charter.html |date=July 14, 2011 }}</ref>
A demise charter operates as a long lease of the vessel, with the charterer completely in charge. In time and voyage charters, the shipowner still runs the ship, but when in port the charterer becomes responsible for loading and unloading the ship within the agreed period of [[laytime]]. If the charterer exceeds the allowed laytime, [[demurrage]]<ref>"Demurrage" is a form of [[liquidated damages]], a penalty for exceeding laytime.</ref> becomes payable.<ref>The ''[[Suisse Atlantique Societe d'Armament SA v NV Rotterdamsche Kolen Centrale|Suisse Atlantique]]" case</ref>
In a voyage charter, the route is pre-arranged and the charterer has little scope to interfere with the programme. By contrast, the time charter is almost a halfway-house between a demise charter and a voyage charter, in that the charterer decides on the voyages and the ports, and instructs the shipowner's crew to comply. This can lead to issues of [[indemnity]]: whereas the shipowner in a voyage charter takes responsibility for the ship, in a time charter the shipowner may need to be indemnified against losses or liabilities [[Proximate cause|proximately caused]] by the charterer.
==Legal aspects of charterparties==
Whereas a charterparty is the contract between a shipowner and a charterer, a contract of carriage lies between the shipper and the carrier. A carrier will issue a shipper with a [[bill of lading]], a receipt for cargo shipped which also serves as evidence of the contract of carriage. (In a demise charter, the charterer is the carrier; in a time or voyage charter the shipowner is the carrier).
The US [[Carriage of Goods by Sea Act]] (COGSA), and the UK [[Carriage of Goods by Sea Act 1971]] (which ratifies and incorporates the [[Hague-Visby Rules]]) do NOT apply to charterparties, but do apply to bills of lading (and similar documents such as ships delivery orders, or sea waybills).<ref>[[Carriage of Goods by Sea Act 1992]]</ref>
When a bill of lading is issued to a charterer by the shipowner, the question arises as to which is the dominant document.<ref>''The Draupner'' [1910] AC 450, HL</ref><ref>''The Henryk Sif'' [1982] 1 LL R 456</ref> If a shipper returns a bill of lading to a carrier (perhaps as a [[Pledge (law)|pledge]]), the carrier will hold it only as a token of the pledge.
In both USA and the UK, the COGSA legislation provide a statement of the minimum duties that a carrier owes to the cargo-owner. If the charterer has shipped cargo, charterparty document may incorporate the COGSA or the Harter Act, since the charter is also a cargo-owner. Such an incorporation is valid and enforceable even without the issuance of a bill of lading. In the reverse case, if a carrier issues a third-party shipper with a bill of lading that incorporates charterparty terms, the shipper/cargo-owner would not be liable for fees such as [[demurrage]], which are payable only by a charter.
Lawsuits brought for the breach of an obligation under a charterparty fall within admiralty jurisdiction. If a breach of charter terms creates a maritime lien, the suit may be ''in rem'' (i.e. against the vessel itself).{{citation needed|date=January 2018}}
In pleasure boating, the most frequent charter arrangement is bareboat [[yacht charter]]. A voyage or time charter is used only for larger yachts and is uncommon. Yacht charter flotillas are mostly made up of boats belonging to individuals or companies who only use their boats on a part-time basis or as an investment. A recent innovation in recreational boating is "time-share chartering" whereby several charterers are assigned a certain number of days per month or season in a manner which resembles real-estate time-share.
==Typical clauses==
A charterparty may contain these clauses.
===Bunker clause===
A [[bunkers|bunker]] clause stipulates that the charterer shall accept and pay for all fuel oil in the vessel's bunkers at port of delivery and conversely, (owners) shall pay for all fuel oil in the vessel's bunkers at port of re-delivery at current price at the respective ports. It is customary to agree upon a certain minimum and maximum quantity in bunkers on re-delivery of the vessel. Since the [[OW Bunker]] test case, ship operators need to take care to ensure that bunker supply terms are suitable.
===Ship clause===
Under this clause, the owner of the ship writes clearly that the ship would be seaworthy at the start of the voyage in every respect, in other words, the ship would be appropriate to travel to the country for which it is taken.
===Ice clause===
An ice clause is inserted in a [[bill of lading]] or a charterparty when a vessel is bound for a port or ports which may be closed to shipping by ice when the vessel arrives or after the vessel's arrival.
===Lighterage clause===
A lighterage clause is inserted into charter-parties which show as port of discharge any safe port in a certain range, e.g. Havre/Hamburg range.
===Negligence clause===
A negligence clause tends to exclude shipowner's or carrier's liability for loss or damage resulting from an act, default or neglect of the master, mariner, pilot or the servants of the carrier in the navigation of manoeuvring of a ship, not resulting, however, from want of due diligence by the owners of the ship or any of them or by the ship's husband or manager.
===Ready berth clause===
A ready berth clause is inserted in a charterparty, ''i.e.'' a stipulation to the effect that [[layday]]s will begin to count as soon as the vessel has arrived at the port of loading or discharge "whether in berth or not". It protects shipowner's interests against delays which arise from ships having to wait for a [[berth (moorings)|berth]].
==See also== * [[Air charter]]
==References== {{Multiple issues|{{more citations needed|date=January 2018}}{{one source|date=January 2018}}}} {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Ship chartering}}
[[Category:Water transport]] [[Category:Contract law]] [[Category:Ship management]] [[Category:Admiralty law]]

{{Infobox person | image = | image_size = | name = Dan T. Cathy | caption = | birth_name = Daniel Truett Cathy | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1953|3|1}} | birth_place = [[Jonesboro, Georgia]], US | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = American | residence = [[Atlanta, Georgia]], US | education = | alma mater = [[Georgia Southern University]] {{small|(BBA)}} | occupation = Chairman, President and CEO, [[Chick-fil-A]] | known for = | salary = | networth = US $4.7 billion (Sept 2018){{cite web|title=Dan Cathy|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/dan-cathy-1/|website=Forbes|accessdate=26 June 2015}} | spouse = | parents = [[S. Truett Cathy]] and Jeanette (McNeil) Cathy | children = 2 | relatives = [[Bubba Cathy]] (brother) | website = }} '''Daniel Truett Cathy''' (born March 1, 1953) is an American [[billionaire]] businessman. He is chairman, president, and CEO of fast-food chain [[Chick-fil-A]], which was founded and expanded by his father, [[S. Truett Cathy]]. ==Early life== Cathy was born in [[Jonesboro, Georgia]] in 1953 as the second child and first son of Jeanette (McNeil) and [[S. Truett Cathy]]. His father had recently started a restaurant known as the Dwarf House. Cathy has an older sister Trudy and younger brother, [[Bubba Cathy]]. In addition their family fostered numerous children over the years. He began doing radio commercials for his father's original Dwarf House restaurant in [[Hapeville, Georgia]] in the late 1960s, while he was attending local schools. By that time, his father was establishing additional restaurants around Atlanta and Georgia as he created the franchise chain known as [[Chick-fil-A]]. Cathy earned a bachelor's degree in business administration from [[Georgia Southern University]] in 1975. After graduation, he began working full-time for his father's company, which had already been established as a franchise chain.Gatlin, Greg (October 7, 1998). [https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/34869147.html?dids=34869147:34869147&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT "Chick-fil-A hatches expansion plans"], ''[[Boston Herald]]''; accessed September 14, 2014. ==Career== Cathy started as director of operations, eventually being promoted in 2013 to president and CEO. Cathy spends much of his time visiting the chain's 2,000 restaurants. Cathy holds honorary doctorates from the [[University of West Georgia]], [[Anderson University (South Carolina)|Anderson College]], Carver Bible College, and [[Pepperdine University]]. His family runs the [[WinShape Foundation]], a non-profit which supports a group of [[Southern Baptist]] ministries. ==Same-sex marriage== {{see also|Chick-fil-A same-sex marriage controversy}} Cathy has said that he disagrees with [[same-sex marriage]], and supports conservative Christian causes.Severson, Kim (July 25, 2012). [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/26/us/gay-rights-uproar-over-chick-fil-a-widens.html "Chick-fil-A Thrust Back Into Spotlight on Gay Rights"], ''[[New York Times]]''; accessed September 14, 2014. But in March 2014, he told the ''[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]'' that it had been a "mistake" for the WinShape Foundation to "support political or social agendas" in the period before 2012, when this was reported and a national controversy broke out at a time of debate about same-sex marriages. He has been working with [[LGBT]] activist Shane Windmeyer of [[Campus Pride]] since 2012. Windmeyer stated that WinShape and the Chick-fil-A Foundation had "dramatically" cut donations to groups considered to be anti-gay by gay marriage supporters. Cathy said that,
"While we evaluate individual donations on an annual basis, our giving is focused on three key areas: youth and education, leadership and family enrichment and serving the local communities in which we operate. Our intent is to not support political or social agendas. This has been the case for more than 60 years. The Chick-fil-A culture and service tradition in our restaurants is to treat every person with honor, dignity and respect and to serve great food with genuine hospitality."{{cite web|url=http://www.myajc.com/news/business/cathy-seeks-to-put-gay-marriage-flap-behind-chick-/nfCHj|title="Cathy Seeks to Put Gay Marriage Flap Behind Chick-fil-A" ''www.myajc.com'' March 14, 2014|accessdate=September 10, 2014}}[http://goqnotes.com/27860/new-chick-fil-a-filings-show-decrease-in-anti-lgbt-funding "New Chick-fil-A filings show decrease in anti-LGBT funding"], goqnotes.com; accessed September 14, 2014.
==Personal life== Cathy is married, with two children. He and his family live in [[Atlanta, Georgia]]. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120309210046/http://chick-fil-a.com/Press/Bios/Dan Dan T. Cathy President and Chief Operating Officer] via [[Chick-fil-A]] *[http://www.cathyfamily.com/ Cathy Family website] {{DEFAULTSORT:Cathy, Dan T.}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1953 births]]] [[Category:Cathy family]] [[Category:Georgia Southern University alumni]] [[Category:Southern Baptists]] [[Category:Chick-fil-A]] [[Category:People from Jonesboro, Georgia]] [[Category:American billionaires]] [[Category:20th-century American businesspeople]] {{US-business-bio-1950s-stub}}

'''Downtown Edmonton''' is the [[central business district]] of [[Edmonton]], [[Alberta]]. Located at the geographical centre of the city, the downtown area is bounded by 109 Street to the west, 105 Avenue to the north, 97 Street to the east, 97 Avenue and Rossdale Road to the south, and the [[North Saskatchewan River]] to the southeast.
Surrounding neighbourhoods include [[Oliver, Edmonton|Oliver]] to the west, [[Queen Mary Park]], [[Central McDougall]], and [[McCauley, Edmonton|McCauley]] to the north, [[Boyle Street]] and [[Riverdale, Edmonton|Riverdale]] to the east, and [[Rossdale, Edmonton|Rossdale]] to the south.
The residents of Downtown Edmonton are represented by the Downtown Edmonton [[Neighborhood council|Community League]], established in 1999, which runs a [[Community centre|community hall]] located at 100 Avenue and 103 Street.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.decl.org/about/ |title=Downtown Edmonton Community League |publisher=Downtown Edmonton Community League |access-date=October 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last =Kuban |first =Ron |title =Edmonton's Urban Villages: The Community League Movement |publisher =University of Alberta Press |year =2005 |isbn =9781459303249}}</ref>
==Districts and streets== ===Arts District and Churchill Square=== [[File:Churchill square edmonton.jpg|thumb|left|[[Churchill Square, Edmonton|Churchill Square]] is a major [[public square]] in Downtown Edmonton.]] {{Further information|Churchill Square, Edmonton}} The arts district is in the eastern part of the core with many award winning institutions like the [[Francis Winspear Centre for Music]] (home of the [[Edmonton Symphony Orchestra]]) and the [[Citadel Theatre]]. [[Edmonton City Hall]] is also located here with all these buildings facing onto Sir Winston Churchill Square. It is also the site of the new [[Art Gallery of Alberta]], which opened in early 2010, and the [[Stanley A. Milner Library]], [[Edmonton Public Library|Edmonton Public Library's]] main branch.
[[Churchill Square, Edmonton|Churchill Square]] (Officially "Sir Winston Churchill Square") is the main downtown square in [[Edmonton]], and is the heart of the Arts District. The square plays host to a large majority of festivals and events in [[Edmonton Capital Region|Greater Edmonton]]. It is bordered on the north by 102A Avenue, on the west by 100 Street, on the south by 102 Avenue (Harbin Road) and on the east by Rue Hull (99) Street. Recently, the portion of 102A Avenue that cut Churchill Square off from Edmonton's City Hall has been closed off to vehicular traffic as a way to better connect Churchill Square with the fountains and some festivities on the plaza at City Hall.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cbc.ca/canada/edmonton/story/2009/12/14/edm-road-closed.html |title=Avenue between City Hall and Churchill Square to close |date=December 14, 2009 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=September 21, 2011}}</ref>
=== Government Centre === [[File:Legislature-Building-Edmonton-Alberta-Canada-02AA.jpg|thumb|The [[Alberta Legislature Building]] is a prominent [[landmark]] in Government Centre.]] Government Centre is an informal district located at the southwest corner of the downtown core and is the home of the Alberta [[Alberta Legislature|provincial government]]. The most notable feature of this part of downtown is the [[Alberta Legislature Building]] and its surrounding parks, fountains, and gardens.
An underground pedway system connects the Legislature to several of the surrounding buildings, including the historic Bowker Building and the Frederick W. Haultain Building.
Federal government offices were housed in the Federal Building at the north-east corner of Government Centre until they relocated to [[Canada Place (Edmonton)|Canada Place]], located at the east edge of downtown, in the 1980s. The Federal Building is undergoing a $356 million renovation due to be completed in 2015 for provincial government offices and a new underground parking structure.<ref>Archie McLean, "Federal building to get $356M makeover",[http://www2.canada.com/edmontonjournal/news/story.html?id=8a5b1566-7738-44ea-a33f-12f855ebc74f Edmonton Journal], June 18, 2008.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infrastructure.alberta.ca/3562.htm |title=The Federal Building and Centennial Plaza Project |author=Government of Alberta Ministry of Infrastructure |publisher=Government of Alberta |accessdate=September 21, 2011}}</ref>
Transit service is provided by the [[Government Centre Transit Centre]] located near the Federal Building and by [[Grandin station|Grandin LRT Station]] located just to the west.
=== Jasper Avenue === {{Main|Jasper Avenue}} [[File:Jasper ave.JPG|thumb|[[Jasper Avenue]] and 103 Street in Downtown Edmonton. Jasper Avenue is the city's "[[main street]]".]] Jasper Avenue is the city's "main street". It starts at 77 Street in the east, running south west along the south edge of [[Boyle Street]] until it reaches the downtown core. It then runs due west through downtown and the neighbourhood of Oliver until it reaches 125 Street. Jasper Avenue is a major public transit route as several of Edmonton's busiest bus routes travel along it. The LRT travels underneath Jasper Avenue between 99 and 110 Streets.
Jasper Avenue has no [[street number]] but sits where 101 Avenue would otherwise be. Jasper Avenue is home to many of [[heritage buildings in Edmonton|Edmonton's oldest heritage buildings]] (for example the [[Hotel Macdonald]]) and some of [[list of tallest buildings in Edmonton|Edmonton's tallest office towers]], including [[Canadian Western Bank Place]] and [[Scotia Place]]; however, the presence of the former limits that of the latter, and many tall buildings are found just off Jasper where land is easier to obtain. Together with help from nearby streets like 100 Avenue, 104 Street, 101 Street, and 102 Avenue, the Jasper West area (west of 97 Street) is one of the major retail, living, commercial, and entertainment districts of the city.
=== Rice Howard Way === Rice Howard Way comprises 100A Street between Jasper Avenue and 102 Avenue and 101A Avenue between 100 Street and 101 Street. The portion of 101A Avenue between 100A Street and 101 Street was closed to traffic, making it an open air pedestrian walkway. The rest of Rice Howard Way is open to vehicular traffic. Rice Howard Way has a few prominent office towers like Scotia Place and some restaurants.
Rice Howard Way's southern edge (100A Street at Jasper Avenue) has an entrance to the [[Central station (Edmonton)|Central LRT Station]].
=== Warehouse District and 104 Street === [[File:Warehouse District Compessed.jpg|thumb|The Warehouse District is an area in Downtown Edmonton consisting of repurposed warehouses from the early 20th century.]] The Warehouse District is located between Jasper Avenue and 104 Avenue and between 102 Street and 109 Street. During the first decade of the 20th century, the [[Hudson's Bay Company]] began selling its land holdings in this area, and businesses were quick to move in. Between 1909 and 1914, no fewer than two dozen warehouses were constructed.<ref>Lawrence Herzog, "Edmontons Warehouse District",[http://www.rewedmonton.ca/content_view2?CONTENT_ID=447 Real Estate Weekly, Vol 21 No. 25], June 26, 2003.</ref>
In the later part of the century, warehouses closed and the buildings were redeveloped into commercial enterprises. In the late 1990s lofts were created in these former warehouses. In recent years, the area has seen a revival, with new lofts and condos being constructed or proposed, along with many designer shops.<ref name="104Street">{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/how-104th-street-became-the-heart-of-downtown-edmonton-1.1321099 |title=How 104th Street became the heart of downtown Edmonton |last=Bellefontaine |first=Michelle |date=June 14, 2013 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=January 17, 2015}}</ref> The area also included Canada's first urban format Sobey's Fresh Market, flanking the curved Birks building as the entrance to 104 Street at Jasper Avenue, serving the residential population until its closure in 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/sobeys-closing-store-on-104th-street-1.2688247 |title=Sobeys closing store on 104th Street |date=June 26, 2014 |publisher=CBC News |accessdate=January 17, 2015}}</ref>
104 Street (in between Jasper Avenue and 104 Avenue) is the main street in the Warehouse District and features shops, restaurants, cafes and a variety of services. On Saturdays during the warmer months (May–October), the street hosts Edmonton's original farmer's market, the City Market. The area is also known for [[loft]]s in old warehouses. The street is very dense, and has seen new projects completed in 2009 and 2010 ([[Icon Towers|Icon I and II]]) with the construction of the Fox Towers condo complex at the northwest corner of 104 Street and 102 Avenue underway.<ref name="104Street"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edmontonjournal.com/business/commercial-real-estate/2020+vision+What+will+downtown+Edmonton+look+like+decade/10198815/story.html |title=2020 vision: What will downtown Edmonton look like at the end of the decade? |last=Kent |first=Gordon |date=September 15, 2014 |publisher=Edmonton Journal |accessdate=January 17, 2015}}</ref>
===Ice District & Rogers Place === {{Main|Ice District}} [[File:Ice District Construction - July 2017 - (36228354735).jpg|thumb|Construction in the [[Ice District]] in 2017. It is a [[mixed-use development|mixed-use]] sports and entertainment district in Downtown.]] The Ice District is located between 101 and 104 Street to 103 and 106 Avenue. It is a $2.5 billion [[mixed-use development|mixed-use]] sports and entertainment district being developed on {{convert|10|ha|acre+sqyd}} of land in Downtown.<ref name="name1">{{cite news|last1=Shaw|first1=Stewart|last2=Parrish|first2=Julia|title=Katz Group officially announces new name for downtown arena district|url=http://edmonton.ctvnews.ca/katz-group-officially-announces-new-name-for-downtown-arena-district-1.2466690|accessdate=1 May 2016|agency=CTV News Edmonton|publisher=Bell Media Television|date=13 July 2015}}</ref><ref name="name2">{{cite news|last1=Mah|first1=Bill|title=Oilers CEO says Ice District a ‘crisp and clean’ new name for arena district|url=http://www.edmontonjournal.com/business/commercial-real-estate/meet+cold+District+Edmonton+Area/11210320/story.html|accessdate=1 May 2016|agency=Edmonton Journal|publisher=Postmedia Network Inc.|date=12 July 2015}}</ref> When completed it will be Canada’s largest mixed use and entertainment district.<ref name="icedistrictproperties">{{cite web|title=A Vibrant World-Class Destination|url=http://icedistrictproperties.com/|website=ICE District Properties|publisher=ICE District Properties|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref>
A new arena named [[Rogers Place]], for the [[Edmonton Oilers]]. Was approved in early 2013 the project was approved. Construction of the arena started in March 2014.<ref name="Construction">{{cite news|title=Rogers Place construction starts Monday|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/rogers-place-construction-starts-monday-1.2557811|accessdate=1 May 2016|agency=CBC News Edmonton|publisher=CBC/Radio Canada|date=3 March 2014}}</ref> briefly closed in October 2012.<ref name="endtalks">{{cite news|title=Edmonton to end arena talks with Oilers' owner Katz|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/edmonton-to-end-arena-talks-with-oilers-owner-katz-1.1132537|accessdate=1 May 2016|agency=CBC News Edmonton|publisher=CBC/Radio-Canada|date=17 October 2012}}</ref> In early 2014 the project was approved, and construction of the arena started in March 2014.<ref name="Construction"/> It was named Rogers Place in December 2013 with an agreement form [[Rogers Communications]] for 10-year naming rights deal.<ref name="nameRogers">{{cite news|title=Downtown arena will be named Rogers Place|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/downtown-arena-will-be-named-rogers-place-1.2449243|accessdate=1 May 2016|agency=CBC Edmonton|issue=CM|publisher=CBC/Radio Canada|date=3 December 2014}}</ref> It opened in September 2016.<ref name="Construction"/>
Phase One started after the Ice District announcement 2014–2016. It has A new Office tower, and attractions along with Rogers Place.<ref name="Phase One">{{cite web|title=Phase One|url=http://icedistrict.com/|website=Ice District|publisher=ICE District JV Inc.|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> [[Edmonton Tower]], Winter Garden, and [[Grand Villa Casino Edmonton]], are expected to open in 2016.<ref name="Phase One"/> The [[MacEwan station|MacEwan LRT Station]] was opened in September 2015.<ref name="Phase One"/><ref name="Phase One"/><ref name="lrtopen">{{cite news|last1=Ramsay|first1=Caley|title=After lengthy delay, Metro Line LRT opens to riders|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2206051/after-lenghty-delay-metro-line-lrt-opens-to-riders/|accessdate=1 May 2016|agency=Global News Edmonton|publisher=Corus Entertainment Inc.|date=6 September 2015}}</ref> The next Phase X will is from 2017–2020.<ref name="Phase One X">{{cite web|title=Phase One X|url=http://icedistrict.com/|website=Ice District|publisher=ICE District JV Inc.|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> This includes [[Stantec Tower]],<ref name="Phase One X"/><ref name="tallest">{{cite news|last1=Kent|first1=Gordon|title=Stantec Tower in Edmonton set to be Canada's tallest outside Toronto|url=http://edmontonjournal.com/business/commercial-real-estate/stantec-tower-set-to-be-canadas-tallest-outside-toronto|agency=Edmonton Journal|publisher=PostMark Media|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> and the [[JW Marriott Edmonton Ice District & Residences]] expected to open in 2018.<ref name="Phase One X"/><ref name="JWmarriot">{{cite web|title=JW Marriott Hotel & Legends Private Residences|url=http://www.emporis.com/buildings/1236690/jw-marriott-hotel-legends-private-residences-edmonton-canada|website=Emporis|publisher=Emporis|accessdate=1 May 2016}}</ref> Other projects include; A public plaza, future residences, and retail attractions, such as a Rexall pharmacy, [[Cineplex Entertainment|Cineplex UltraAVX & VIP Cinemas]], and grocery shopping centres. Opening throughout the 2017–2020 phase.<ref name="Phase One X"/>
== Demographics == In the City of Edmonton's 2014 municipal census, Downtown had a population of {{nts|13148}} living in {{nts|9230}} dwellings,<ref name="2014population">{{cite web |url=http://edmonton.ca/city_government/documents/census/Summary%20Report%20of%20All%20Questions_DOWNTOWN_2014.pdf |title=2014 Municipal Census Summary Report of All Questions - Downtown | date=August 2014 |publisher=City of Edmonton |accessdate=January 17, 2015}}</ref> a 7.8% change from its 2012 population of {{nts|12199}}.<ref name="2012population">{{cite web |url=http://www.edmonton.ca/city_government/documents/Summary_Report_of_All_Questions_DOWNTOWN_2012.pdf |title=2012 Municipal Census Summary Report of All Questions - Downtown |year=2012 |publisher=City of Edmonton |accessdate=January 17, 2015}}</ref> With a land area of {{convert|2.28|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}},<ref name=nbhds/> it had a population density of {{nts|5766.7}} people/km<sup>2</sup> in 2014.<ref name=nbhds/><ref name="2014population"/> [[File:Edmonton Downtown Population.png|thumb|Population of Downtown Edmonton from 1986 to 2005.]] {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Female ! Male ! Total ! Census type |- | 1986 | 2,170 | 2,880 | 5,050 | [[Census in Canada|Federal]] |- | 1991 | 2,380 | 3,015 | 5,395 | Federal |- | [[Canada 1996 Census|1996]] | 2,205 | 2,925 | 5,130 | Federal |- | [[Canada 2001 Census|2001]] | 2,845 | 3,330 | 6,175 | Federal |- | 2005 | 4,216 | 4,811 | 9,027 | Municipal |- | 2008 | 5,008 | 5,351 | 10,359 | Municipal |- | 2009 | 5,455 | 6,117 | 11,572 | Municipal<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edmonton.ca/city_government/documents/PDF/Summary_Report_of_All_Questions_DOWNTOWN.pdf | title=2009 Municipal Census Summary Report of All Questions - Downtown |year=2009 |publisher=City of Edmonton |accessdate=January 17, 2015}}</ref> |- | 2012 | 5,743 | 6,456 | 12,199 | Municipal<ref name="2012population"/> |- | 2014 | 6,325 | 6,823 | 13,148 | Municipal<ref name="2014population"/> |}
== Education == [[File:Grant MacEwan North Towers Edmonton Alberta Canada 02.jpg|thumb|[[MacEwan University]]'s City Centre Campus is located at the northern edge of the downtown core. It is one of several [[post-secondary education|post-secondary]] institutions operating in downtown.]] There are several institutions providing educational opportunities in the downtown core. The largest of these is [[MacEwan University]] whose City Centre Campus is located along the northern edge of the downtown core between 105 Street and 112 Street, and between 104 Avenue and 105 Avenue. This site used to be part of an [[old Canadian National rail yard]] that started redevelopment in the 1990s. MacEwan University also operates the Alberta College Campus located near the southern edge of the downtown core on McDonald Drive.
The [[University of Alberta]] has redeveloped the site of the Bay building on Jasper Avenue between 102 Street and 103 Street as Enterprise Square (2008). "The building will house TEC Edmonton, a jointly operated research commercialization centre presently located in the U of A's Research Transition Facility."<ref>The University [http://www.expressnews.ualberta.ca/article.cfm?id=6997 describes its plans] for use of the Bay building in their press release announcing approval to purchase the building.</ref> The opening of Enterprise Square marks the University's 100th Anniversary and first presence north of the river since it was founded in 1908. Enterprise Square also houses the University's Alumni Services, Faculty of Extension programs, and a U of A Bookstore.
The [[Edmonton Public Schools|Edmonton Public School Board]] operates a high school, Centre High, in the redeveloped Boardwalk and Revolution buildings.
[[NorQuest College]] is located between 107 Street and 108 Street at 102 Avenue and provides upgrading and diploma services.
== Historic buildings == {{expand section|date=January 2015}} [[File:McKay Avenue School (front).JPG|thumb|Completed in 1905, [[McKay Avenue School]] is a historical landmark in Downtown Edmonton, and presently houses the [[Edmonton Public School Board]] Archives and Museum.]] [[McKay Avenue School]] is an important historical building located in downtown Edmonton. Named for Dr. William Morrison MacKay, a doctor with the [[Hudson's Bay Company]] and Alberta's first doctor.<ref>{{cite book|last=Sanderson|first=Kay|title=200 Remarkable Alberta Women|year=1999|publisher=Famous Five Foundation|location=Calgary|page=10|url=http://www.ourfutureourpast.ca/loc_hist/page.aspx?id=917770}}</ref> Construction began in 1904 when the cornerstone was laid by the [[Governor General of Canada]], [[Gilbert Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound, 4th Earl of Minto|Lord Minto]]. The building was named a provincial historic resource in 1976. Due to declining enrollments, the school was closed in 1983. Today, the building has a new lease on life, and is the home of the [[Edmonton Public School Board]] Archives and Museum. In addition to its educational role, the building was also used by the [[Alberta Legislature]] during 1906 and 1907, when the legislature's first two sittings were held here. The 1881 Schoolhouse, an older wood frame building and Edmonton's oldest school, is located on the same site.<ref>[http://archives.epsb.net/history.htm History of McKay Avenue School] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130213113129/http://archives.epsb.net/history.htm |date=2013-02-13 }}</ref>
== Retail == {{expand section|date=January 2015}} [[Edmonton City Centre]] (formerly Eaton Centre and Edmonton Centre) is a two part shopping mall with over 170 services on 102 Avenue. It is anchored by [[Hudson's Bay (retailer)|Hudson's Bay]], [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation|CBC]], [[Winners]] and [[Landmark Cinemas (Canada)|Landmark Cinemas]]. It has four office towers (using the mall as a podium), plus a [[Delta Hotels|Delta Hotel]]. When Edmonton Centre and the Eaton Centre became one in the late 1990s after the demise of Eaton's, a newer and larger pedestrian skyway was built to connect the two malls which also contains a number of shops. Also in the late 1990s (after the malls became one), the mall received a makeover itself. Recently the mall itself has been attracting some higher end retailers.
== Transportation == [[File:Bay-Enterprise Square LRT Station (20581703943).jpg|thumb|the [[Edmonton Transit System]]'s [[Edmonton Light Rail Transit|light rail system]] runs through Downtown Edmonton.]] {{main|Transportation in Edmonton}} [[Edmonton Transit System]]'s [[Edmonton Light Rail Transit|light rail system]] runs beneath the downtown core, with one station at [[Churchill Square, Edmonton|Churchill Square]] ([[Churchill station (Edmonton)|Churchill LRT Station]]), three stations along Jasper Avenue ([[Central station (Edmonton)|Central]], [[Bay/Enterprise Square station|Bay/Enterprise Square]], and [[Corona station (Edmonton)|Corona]]) and one station at government centre ([[Grandin station|Grandin]]). From Grandin station, the LRT continues south over the [[North Saskatchewan River]] to three [[University of Alberta]] stations ([[University station (Edmonton)|University]], [[Health Sciences/Jubilee station|Health Sciences]], and [[South Campus/Fort Edmonton Park station|South Campus]]), as a part of the [[Capital Line|South extension]]. From Churchill Station, the LRT travels north east towards [[Commonwealth Stadium, Edmonton|Commonwealth Stadium]] and [[Northlands Coliseum]]. A [[Metro Line|second LRT line]], connecting to [[MacEwan University]], [[Royal Alexandra Hospital, Edmonton|Royal Alexandra Hospital]], [[Kingsway Mall]], and the [[Northern Alberta Institute of Technology]] (NAIT), opened in 2015. A third line under construction, the [[Valley Line (Edmonton)|Valley Line]], will connect downtown to [[Mill Woods]].
The [[Edmonton Pedway]] is a pedestrian skywalk system that consists of [[skyway|bridges]] and [[tunnels]] connecting to various buildings and LRT stations in the downtown area.
A [[High Level Bridge Streetcar|heritage streetcar]] line operates during the summer months from Jasper Avenue to [[Old Strathcona]] over the [[High Level Bridge Edmonton | High Level Bridge]].

{{short description|US business cluster of defense and technology companies}} The '''Dulles Technology Corridor''' is a [[business cluster]] containing many [[Defense contractor|defense]] and technology companies, located in [[Northern Virginia]] near [[Washington Dulles International Airport]]. The area was called "The Silicon Valley of the East" by ''[[Atlantic (magazine)|Atlantic]]'' magazine.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2011/06/the-silicon-valley-of-the-east-is-washington-dc/240055/ | title='The Silicon Valley of the East' Is Washington, D.C. | author=Derek Thompson | work=The Atlantic | date=June 7, 2011 | accessdate=December 13, 2014}}</ref> It was dubbed the "'''Netplex'''" in a 1993 article by ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' magazine. Another article in 2000 claimed that the area contained "vital electronic pathways that carry more than half of all traffic on the Internet. The region is home to more telecom and satellite companies than any other place on earth."<ref>{{citation |last= Donnelly |first= Sally B. |last2= Zagorin |first2= Adam |date= August 14, 2000 |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,997688-1,00.html |title= D.C. Dotcom |journal= [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate= 2012-10-12 }}</ref>
The Dulles Technology Corridor is a descriptive term for a string of communities that lie along and between [[Virginia State Route 267]] (the Dulles Toll Road and Dulles Greenway), and [[Virginia State Route 7]] (Leesburg Pike and Harry Byrd Highway). It especially includes the communities, from east to west, of [[Tysons Corner, Virginia|Tysons Corner]], [[Reston, Virginia|Reston]], [[Herndon, Virginia|Herndon]], [[Sterling, Virginia|Sterling]], and [[Ashburn, Virginia|Ashburn]]. These communities are in [[Fairfax County, Virginia|Fairfax]] and [[Loudoun County, Virginia|Loudoun]] counties, which are the second-highest and [[Highest-income counties in the United States#100 highest-income counties by median household income|highest income counties]] in the U.S. as of 2011, coinciding with the national technology and local internet boom of the 1990s and local technology spending after the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]].
==Internet infrastructure and data centers== As of 2009, more than 50% of all U.S. Internet traffic travelled through Northern Virginia.<ref name="us news"/> In 2013, as much as 70% of the world's Internet traffic travelled through data centers in Loudoun County.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.loudountimes.com/index.php/news/article/another_joins_data_center_rush123/ | title=Another company joins data center rush | author=Andrew Sharbel | work=Loudoun-Times-Mirror | date=May 29, 2012 | accessdate=February 15, 2013}}</ref>{{better source|date=February 2014}} In his book ''Tubes'', author Andrew Blum calls [[Ashburn, Virginia]]—a community within the Dulles Technology Corridor—"the bullseye of America's Internet".<ref name="tubes">{{cite web | url=https://gizmodo.com/5913934/the-bullseye-of-americas-internet | title=The Bullseye of America’s Internet | author=Andrew Blum | work=Gizmodo | date=Jan 16, 2013 | accessdate=February 23, 2014}}</ref> The Dulles Technology Corridor serves as headquarters for domain name registrar [[Network Solutions]] and network infrastructure company [[Verisign]]. The region contains the [[Internet Society]], and used to contain the mainframe that houses the master list of all Internet domain names.
The Dulles Technology Corridor includes Ashburn, Virginia's "Data Center Alley",<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.datacenterknowledge.com/archives/2011/08/28/washpost-profiles-ashburn-data-center-alley/ | title=WashPost Profiles Ashburn 'Data Center Alley' | author=Rich Miller | work=Data Center Knowledge | date=August 28, 2011 | accessdate=February 15, 2013}}</ref> described by the ''[[Washington Business Journal]]'' as "an area that is quickly emerging as a national hub for data storage facilities".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bizjournals.com/washington/print-edition/2011/12/02/equinix-plotting-massive-ashburn-data.html | title=Equinix plotting massive Ashburn data complex | work=Washington Business Journal | author=Daniel J. Sernovitz | date=December 2, 2011 | accessdate=February 15, 2013}}</ref> The corridor also has [[data centers]] in [[Sterling, Virginia|Sterling]], [[Herndon, Virginia|Herndon]], [[Reston, Virginia|Reston]], and [[Tysons Corner, Virginia|Tysons Corner]]. The area is a growing home for major data centers including those of [[Amazon Web Services|Amazon Web Services (AWS)]]'s US East region, where an estimated 70% of AWS [[IP address]]es are housed.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.datacenterknowledge.com/archives/2013/01/15/amazon-to-add-capacity-to-us-east-region/ | title=Amazon Adding Cloud Capacity in Northern Virginia | work=Data Center Knowledge | author=Rich Miller | date=January 15, 2013 | accessdate=February 15, 2013}}</ref> [[Wikimedia Foundation]] has its primary data center in the corridor.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://blog.wikimedia.org/2013/01/19/wikimedia-sites-move-to-primary-data-center-in-ashburn-virginia/ | title = Wikimedia sites to move to primary data center in Ashburn, Virginia | author=Guillaume Paumier | publisher = Wikimedia | date = January 19, 2013}}</ref> According to ''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'', "Northern Virginia remains popular, in part because it has some of the country's cheapest electricity rates."<ref name="us news">{{cite web | url=https://www.usnews.com/news/energy/articles/2009/03/24/the-internets-hidden-energy-hogs-data-servers | title=The Internet's Hidden Energy Hogs: Data Servers | author=Kent Garber | work=U.S. News & World Report | date=March 24, 2009 | accessdate=February 15, 2013}}</ref>
==Business environment== The Dulles Technology Corridor has access to a highly educated workforce. Of adults aged 25 and over, 58.2% in Fairfax County<ref>{{cite web | url=http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/51/51059.html | title=Fairfax County, Virginia | work=State & County QuickFacts | publisher=United States Census Bureau | date=January 10, 2013 | accessdate=February 15, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/603ujafKH?url=http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/51/51059.html | archivedate=July 10, 2011 | df= }}</ref> and 57.6% in Loudoun County<ref>{{cite web | url=http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/51/51107.html | title=Loudoun County, Virginia | work=State & County QuickFacts | publisher=United States Census Bureau | date=January 10, 2013 | accessdate=February 15, 2013 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60AGx39z3?url=http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/51/51107.html | archivedate=July 14, 2011 | df= }}</ref> have a bachelor's degree or higher, compared with 28.2% for the U.S. as a whole.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://quickfacts.census.gov/qfd/states/00000.html | title=USA | work=State & County QuickFacts | publisher=United States Census Bureau | date=January 10, 2013 | accessdate=February 15, 2013}}</ref>
The [[George Washington University]]'s Virginia Science and Technology Campus and the [[Howard Hughes Medical Institute]]'s [[Janelia Farm Research Campus]] are located in the corridor.

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox person | name = Eduardo Saverin | image = Eduardo_Saverin_CHINICT.JPG | caption = Saverin at the [[CHINICT]] conference
on May 25, 2012 | birth_name = Eduardo Luiz Saverin | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1982|03|19|df=y|}} | birth_place = [[São Paulo]], Brazil | residence = [[Singapore]] | citizenship = [[Brazilian nationality law|Brazil]]{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-05-12/facebook-co-founder-may-gain-choosing-singapore-over-u-s-.html|first=Danielle|last=Kucera|first2=Christine|last2=Harper|first3=Jesse|last3=Drucker|title=Facebook Co-Founder May Gain Choosing Singapore Over U.S.|work=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]]|date=12 May 2015|accessdate=14 May 2015|quote=Saverin still does hold Brazilian citizenship, Goodman said.}}{{cite news|url=http://imcmsimages.mediacorp.sg/CMSFileserver/documents/006/PDF/20120517/1705HNP008.pdf |title=Saverin 'has no plans to become S'pore citizen' |work=[[Today (Singapore newspaper)|Today]] |date=2012-05-17 |accessdate=2012-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130526034613/http://imcmsimages.mediacorp.sg/CMSFileserver/documents/006/PDF/20120517/1705HNP008.pdf |archivedate=May 26, 2013 }}
[[United States nationality law|United States]] (1998–2011) | alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] {{small|(BA)}} | known_for = Co-founder of [[Facebook]] | net_worth = [[US$]]9.1 billion{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/eduardo-saverin|work=[[Forbes]]|title=Eduardo Saverin Net Worth}} (2018) | spouse = Elaine Andriejanssen (m. 2015) | URL = {{URL|https://www.facebook.com/saverin}} }} '''Eduardo Luiz Saverin''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|æ|v|ər|ɪ|n}}; {{IPA-pt|eduˈaɾdu luˈis ˈsaveɾĩ|lang}}; born March 19, 1982){{cite news|url=https://www.federalregister.gov/articles/2012/04/30/2012-10274/quarterly-publication-of-individuals-who-have-chosen-to-expatriate|author=[[Internal Revenue Service]]|title=Quarterly Publication of Individuals, Who Have Chosen to Expatriate, as Required by Section 6039G|work=[[Federal Register]]|date=2012}} is a Brazilian-born entrepreneur and [[angel investor]].{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-05-11/facebook-co-founder-saverin-gives-up-u-s-citizenship-before-ipo.html|first1=Danielle|last1=Kucera|first2=Sanat|last2=Vallikappen|first3=Christine|last3=Harper|title=Facebook Co-Founder Saverin Gives Up U.S. Citizenship Before IPO|work=Bloomberg L.P.|date=2012-05-11|accessdate=2012-05-11}} Saverin is one of the co-founders of [[Facebook]]. In 2012, he owned 53 million Facebook shares{{cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1326801/000118143112030861/xslF345X02/rrd345645.xml|title=UNITED STATES SECURITIES AND EXCHANGE COMMISSION INITIAL STATEMENT OF BENEFICIAL OWNERSHIP OF SECURITIES - Eduardo Saverin|date=17 May 2012|author=Eduardo Saverin|work=[[U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission]]}} (approximately 2% of all outstanding shares), valued at approximately $2 billion at the time.https://www.forbes.com/sites/briansolomon/2012/05/18/eduardo-saverins-net-worth-publicly-revealed-more-than-2-billion-in-facebook-alone/#26d547432ac4{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/#51684e38251c|title=The World's Billionaires 2017|website=Forbes|access-date=2018-02-09}} He also invested in early-stage startups such as [[Qwiki]]Bosker, Bianca, [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/01/20/eduardo-saverin-facebook-qwiki_n_811763.html "Facebook Co-Founder Eduardo Saverin Invests In Qwiki"] and [[Jumio]].Wauters, Robin, [https://techcrunch.com/2011/03/17/exclusive-facebook-co-founder-eduardo-saverin-leads-6-5m-round-for-jumio/ "Exclusive: Facebook Co-Founder Eduardo Saverin Leads $6.5M Round For Jumio"], ''[[TechCrunch]]'', Thursday, March 17, 2011 Saverin [[renunciation of citizenship|renounced]] his U.S. citizenship in September 2011,{{cite news |last=Mathews|first=Merrill|date=23 May 2012|title=In Praise Of Eduardo Saverin's Tax Avoidance|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/merrillmatthews/2012/05/23/in-praise-of-eduardo-saverins-tax-avoidance/#63b75b651ade|newspaper=[[Forbes]]|location= |access-date=9 February 2016}}{{cite news |date=18 May 2012|title=So How Much Did He Really Save?|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303360504577410571011995562|newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]]|access-date=9 February 2016}} and therefore avoided an estimated $700 million in capital gains taxes; this generated some media attention and controversy.{{cite news |last=McCormick|first=Jason|date=11 July 2012|title=5 citizens who left the United States to avoid paying tax|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/media/5-citizens-who-left-the-us-to-avoid-paying-tax/|newspaper=[[CBS News]]|location= |publisher= |accessdate=17 June 2014}}{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/timworstall/2012/05/12/saverins-citizenship-renunciation-before-facebook-ipo-will-increase-not-reduce-his-tax-bill/ |title=IPO Will Increase, Not Reduce, His Tax Bill |work=Forbes |first=Tim |last=Worstall |date=May 12, 2012 |accessdate=May 12, 2012}} Saverin stated that he renounced his citizenship because of his "interest in working and living in Singapore" where he has been since 2009,{{cite news|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/deals/2012/05/17/facebook-co-founder-saverin-fires-back-at-misinformation/|author=David Benoit|title=Facebook Co-Founder Saverin Fires Back At ‘Misinformation’|date=17 May 2012}} and denied that he left the U.S. to avoid paying taxes. == Early life and education == Eduardo Luiz Saverin was born in the city of [[São Paulo]], to a wealthy [[Jewish]] Brazilian family,{{cite book|last1=Mezrich|first1=Ben|author-link=Ben Mezrich|title=[[The Accidental Billionaires]]|publisher=[[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]]|isbn=978-0-385-52937-2}}[http://www.thejc.com/lifestyle/lifestyle-features/39327/the-social-network-how-jewish-facebook The Social Network: How Jewish is Facebook?], ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'', Jennifer Lipman, October 14, 2010{{cite web|last1=Amormim|first1=Lucas|title=Zuckerberg: jovem, bilionário e... trapaceiro?|url=http://exame.abril.com.br/revista-exame/edicoes/950/noticias/jovem-bilionario-trapaceiro-492991|website=[[Exame]]|publisher=[[Editora Abril]]|accessdate=23 May 2016|language=Portuguese|trans-title=Zuckerberg: young billionaire ... cheater?|date=2009}} and his family later moved to [[Rio de Janeiro]]. Saverin's father, Roberto Saverin, was a businessman working in clothing, shipping, and real estate.{{cite news |url=http://tecnologia.uol.com.br/ultimas-noticias/redacao/2010/10/22/conheca-quem-e-eduardo-saverin-o-brasileiro-que-ajudou-a-fundar-o-facebook.jhtm |title=Conheça Eduardo Saverin, o brasileiro que ajudou a fundar o Facebook |work=[[Universo Online|UOL]] |first1=Guilherme |last1=Tagiaroli |first2=Ana |last2=Ikeda |date=October 22, 2010 |accessdate=May 12, 2012 |language=Portuguese|trans-title=Meet Eduardo Saverin, the Brazilian who helped found Facebook}} His mother, Sandra, was a psychologist and he has two siblings.{{cite web|last1=Antunes|first1=Anderson|title=Eduardo Saverin Finally Opens Up: 'No Hard Feelings Between Me And Mark Zuckerberg|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/andersonantunes/2012/05/27/eduardo-saverin-finally-opens-up-no-hard-feelings-between-me-and-mark-zuckerberg/#7ac7fd5a5564|work=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=26 May 2016|language=English|date=27 May 2012}} His Romanian-born grandfather, Eugenio Saverin (born Eugen Saverin), is the founder of Tip Top, a chain of children's clothing shops. In 1993, the family immigrated to the U.S., settling in [[Miami]].{{cite web|title=Eduardo Saverin, o brasileiro do Facebook, conta sua história|url=http://veja.abril.com.br/tecnologia/eduardo-saverin-o-brasileiro-do-facebook-conta-sua-historia/|website=[[Veja (magazine)|Veja]]|publisher=[[Grupo Abril]]|accessdate=23 May 2016|language=Portuguese|trans-title=Eduardo Saverin, the Brazilian of Facebook, tells his story |date=26 May 2012}} Saverin attended [[Gulliver Schools|Gulliver Preparatory School]] in Miami. He then attended [[Harvard University]], where he was a resident of [[Eliot House (Harvard College)|Eliot House]], a member of the [[The Phoenix – S K Club|Phoenix S.K. Club]], and president of the Harvard Investment Association. While an undergraduate at Harvard, Saverin took advantage of Brazil's lax [[insider trading]] regulations and made $300,000 via strategic investments in the oil industry.[http://www.cheatsheet.com/breaking-news/the-truth-behind-facebooks-founding-is-finally-revealed.html/?a=viewall The Truth Behind Facebook's Founding is Finally Revealed][https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=106742510 "A Facebook Tale: Founder Unfriends Pals on Way Up"], NPR In 2006, Saverin graduated ''[[magna cum laude]]'' from Harvard University with a [[bachelor's degree]] in economics.{{cite web|url=https://newsroom.fb.com/founder-bios|title=Facebook Founders Bios|work=[[Facebook]]|language=English}} He is a member of the [[Alpha Epsilon Pi]] fraternity (Eta Psi chapter of Harvard University).{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/eduardo-saverin-10-things-know-about-facebook-co-founder-696434|title=Eduardo Saverin: 10 Things To Know About The Facebook Co-Founder|date=2012-05-04|work=International Business Times|access-date=2017-03-28}} == Career == During his junior year at Harvard, Saverin met fellow Harvard undergraduate, sophomore [[Mark Zuckerberg]]. Noting the lack of a dedicated social networking website for Harvard students, the two worked together to launch The Facebook in 2004. As co-founder, Saverin held the role of [[chief financial officer]] and business manager. On May 15, 2012, [[Business Insider]] obtained and released an exclusive email from Zuckerberg detailing how he cut Saverin from Facebook and [[Stock dilution|diluted]] his stake.{{cite web|last1=Carlson|first1=Nicholas|title=EXCLUSIVE: Here's The Email Zuckerberg Sent To Cut His Cofounder Out Of Facebook |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/exclusive-heres-the-email-zuckerberg-sent-to-cut-his-cofounder-out-of-facebook-2012-5?IR=T|website=Business Insider|publisher=Business Insider Inc|accessdate=9 February 2016|date=15 May 2012}} A lawsuit filed by Facebook against Saverin, arguing that the stock-purchase agreements Saverin signed in October 2005 was invalid. Saverin then filed a suit against Zuckerberg alleging Zuckerberg spent Facebook's money (Saverin's money) on personal expenses over the summer.{{cite web | url=https://www.businessinsider.com/how-mark-zuckerberg-booted-his-co-founder-out-of-the-company-2012-5/?IR=T | title=EXCLUSIVE: How Mark Zuckerberg booted his co-founder out of the company | accessdate=22 November 2018}} Both suits were settled out of court. Terms of the settlement were not disclosed and the company affirmed Saverin's title as co-founder of Facebook. Saverin signed a [[non-disclosure agreement|non-disclosure contract]] after the settlement.{{cite journal|last=Carvalho dos Santos|first=Alexandre|author2=Marcelo Rainho|date=October 2009|title=A misteriosa história do brasileiro que fundou o Facebook|journal=[[Superinteressante]]|publisher=[[Editora Abril]]|location=São Paulo|issue=270|pages=94–97|issn=0104-1789|oclc= 60743498|language=Portuguese|trans-title="The mysterious story of the Brazilian who founded Facebook."}} In 2010, Saverin co-founded Aporta, an online portal for charity.{{cite web|title=Eduardo Saverin - CrunchBase|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/person/eduardo-saverin#/|work=[[TechCrunch#CrunchBase|CrunchBase]]|accessdate=26 May 2016|language=English}} In 2016, Saverin's fund closed initial deals of over $140 million in Asia, including $30 million in regional logistics startup [http://www.ninjavan.co Ninja Van].{{cite web|last1=Russell|first1=Jon|title=Facebook co-founder Eduardo Saverin’s new fund closes initial $140 Million for deals in Asia|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/05/19/facebook-co-founder-eduardo-saverins-new-fund-closes-initial-140m-for-deals-in-asia/|work=[[TechCrunch]]|accessdate=23 May 2016|language=English|date=19 May 2016}} ==Personal life== Saverin met Elaine Andriejanssen, a [[Chinese Indonesian]] woman who was educated at [[Raffles Girls' School (Secondary)|Raffles Girls' School]] and [[Tufts University]] comes from a family which runs several businesses in Indonesia.{{cite web|last1=Chia|first1=Stacey|title=Eduardo Saverin's fiancee studied at Raffles Girls' School, Indonesian family runs several businesses|url=http://women.asiaone.com/women/people/eduardo-saverins-fiancee-studied-raffles-girls-school-indonesian-family-runs-several|website=AsiaOne|publisher=Singapore Press Holdings Ltd|accessdate=30 July 2015|date=20 June 2015}} On March 27, 2014, they got engaged and were married on June 25, 2015, in the [[French Riviera]].{{cite web|last1=Iyengar|first1=Rishi|title=Facebook Co-Founder Eduardo Saverin Confirms News of Wedding in Facebook Post|url=http://time.com/3972692/eduardo-saverin-wedding-facebook-post-elaine-andriejanssen/|website=TIME|publisher=Time Inc|accessdate=9 February 2016|date=26 July 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Karmali|first1=Naazneen|title=Secret Wedding Celebration Of Facebook Co-Founder Eduardo Saverin Kicks Off|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/naazneenkarmali/2015/06/25/secret-wedding-celebration-of-facebook-co-founder-eduardo-saverin-kicks-off/|website=Forbes|accessdate=30 July 2015|date=25 June 2015}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * Saverin, Eduardo, [https://www.cnbc.com/id/39675388/ "Facebook Co-Founder Speaks Publicly: What I Learned From Watching 'The Social Network'"], [[CNBC]], Friday, 15 Oct 2010. == External links == {{Commons category}} *{{Facebook|saverin}} *[https://www.forbes.com/profile/eduardo-saverin/ Profile] at ''[[Forbes]]'' *{{Worldcat id|lccn-no2009-108504}} {{Facebook navbox|state = show}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saverin, Eduardo}} [[Category:1982 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Businesspeople from São
