revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox Officeholder | name = Irakli Garibashvili
{{small|{{nobold|ირაკლი ღარიბაშვილი}}}} | image = Irakli Garibashvili 2013. 2 (cropped).jpg | office = 11th [[Prime Minister of Georgia]] | president = [[Giorgi Margvelashvili]] | term_start = November 20, 2013 | term_end = December 30, 2015 | predecessor = [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]] | successor = [[Giorgi Kvirikashvili]] | office1 = [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Georgia)|Minister of Internal Affairs]] | primeminister1 = [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]] | term_start1 = October 25, 2012 | term_end1 = November 17, 2013 | predecessor1 = [[Ekaterine Zguladze]] {{small|(Acting)}} | successor1 = [[Aleksandre Chikaidze]] | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|6|28|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic|Georgian SSR]], [[Soviet Union|USSR]]
{{small|(now [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]])}} | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = Nunuka Tamazashvili | children = Nikoloz
Andria
Gabriel
Nino | party = [[Georgian Dream]] | alma_mater = [[Tbilisi State University]]
[[Pantheon-Sorbonne University]] | religion = [[Georgian Orthodox Church|Georgian Orthodoxy]] | signature = Gharibashvili signature.svg }} '''Irakli Garibashvili''' ({{lang-ka|ირაკლი ღარიბაშვილი}}, also transliterated as '''Gharibashvili'''; born June 28, 1982[http://government.gov.ge/index.php?lang_id=ENG&sec_id=202 Prime Minister of Georgia: Irakli Garibashvili] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203025133/http://government.gov.ge/index.php?lang_id=ENG&sec_id=202 |date=December 3, 2013 }}. Government of Georgia. Retrieved November 24, 2013.) was the [[Prime Minister of Georgia]] from November 20, 2013 until his resignation on December 29, 2015, and is a former business executive. Garibashvili entered politics with his long-time associate, the businessman [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]], in October 2012. He served as [[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Georgia)|Minister of Internal Affairs]] in the [[cabinet of Bidzina Ivanishvili]] from 2012 to 2013. Ivanishvili named Garibashvili as his successor as Prime Minister when he voluntarily stepped down in November 2013.[http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=26705 New PM Wins Confidence Vote]. ''[[Civil Georgia]]''. November 20, 2013. Aged 31 at his ascension, he was the youngest person to assume the PM office. During his term, he was the second [[Lists of state leaders by age#10 youngest serving state leaders|youngest state leader]] in the world, after [[Kim Jong-un]].{{cite news|title=BREAKING: Georgia’s Prime Minister Irakli Garibashvili Resigns|url=http://georgiatoday.ge/news/2465/BREAKING%3A-Georgia%E2%80%99s-Prime-Minister-Irakli-Garibashvili-Resigns|accessdate=27 December 2015|publisher=Georgia Today|date=23 December 2015}} ==Early career== From 1988 to 1999 Garibashvili attended the secondary school No. 1 in [[Dedoplistsqaro]]. From 1999 to 2005 Garibashvili studied International Relations at [[Tbilisi State University]] (TSU), where he graduated with a master's degree. He also studied at the [[Pantheon-Sorbonne University]] from 2002 to 2004. Since 2004, he has worked with the multi-billionaire [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]]. He started by working for logistics division of the construction company Burji, owned by Ivanshvili's Cartu Group. He became Director General of Ivanishvili's charity foundation Cartu in 2005, a member of the supervisory board of Ivanishvili's Cartu Bank in 2007 and director of the label Georgian Dream founded by Ivanishvili's pop-star son [[Bera Ivanishvili|Bera]] in 2009.{{cite news|title=ირაკლი ღარიბაშვილის ბიოგრაფია|url=http://netgazeti.ge/2013/11/02/25089/|accessdate=December 23, 2015|agency=Netgazeti.ge|language=Georgian}}{{cite web|title=Biography of the Prime Minister|url=http://gov.ge/index.php?lang_id=ENG&sec_id=202|publisher=Government of Georgia|accessdate=December 23, 2015}}{{cite news|title=Georgia: Interior Minister Irakli Gharibashvili Proposed as PM|url=http://www.eurasianet.org/node/67718|accessdate=December 24, 2015|agency=Eurasianet|date=November 2, 2013}} ==Early political career== Garibashvili became involved in the politics of Georgia when Ivanishvili founded his political party [[Georgian Dream–Democratic Georgia]] in February 2012. Garibashvili was one of the founding members and initially headed the party’s revision committee. He was included in the party list of [[Member of Parliament|MP]] candidates for the [[Georgian parliamentary election, 2012|October 2012 parliamentary election]]. After the coalition won the 2012 parliamentary election on October 1, Irakli Garibashvili became a party-list representative of the Georgian Dream – Democratic Georgia party in the 2012 convocation of the [[Parliament of Georgia]].{{cite web|title=Gharibashvili biography| url=http://www.netgazeti.ge/GE/105/News/25089/| publisher=netgazeti.ge|accessdate=July 7, 2015}} ==Minister of Internal Affairs== After Georgian Dream's victory in the 2012 parliamentary election, Garibashvili was appointed as Minister of Internal Affairs in the cabinet of Prime Minister Ivanishvili on October 25, 2012. Garibashvili, then 30 years old and described by the [[Georgian media]] as "Ivanishvili's right-hand man", became the youngest member of Georgia's new government. Reforming the [[Interior Ministry]], an agency overseeing Georgian police, security and intelligence services, as well as the border guard and [[Coast Guard of Georgia|navy]], was a part of the Georgian Dream's pre-election agenda.[http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=25403 New Interior Minister Names his Deputies]. ''Civil Georgia''. October 30, 2012. Retrieved December 8, 2012. From 2012 through 2013, the Interior Ministry arrested several high-ranking officials from the previous government, including the former ministers [[Bachana Akhalaia]] and [[Ivane Merabishvili]]. This led to concerns regarding selective justice and political vengeance and drew criticism from the domestic opposition and the international media.[http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=25495 Ivanishvili: Saakashvili's Lobbying 'Will Not Stop Restoring Justice']. ''Civil Georgia''. November 30, 2012. Accessed December 8, 2012. Garibashvili's agency also faced the post-election spike in crime in Georgia. Garibashvili defended the arrests as being in strict accordance with the law and justice and claimed that the rate of minor crime, albeit increased, was not alarming.[https://web.archive.org/web/20131103141522/http://georgiaonline.ge/news/a1/politics/1353376810.php Interior Minister: Recent arrests are fair]. Georgian Online. November 12, 2012. Accessed December 8, 2012.[http://www.messenger.com.ge/issues/2748_november_30_2012/2748_ani.html Interior Minister speaks about the rise in crime]. ''The Messenger''. November 30, 2012. Accessed December 8, 2012. ==Prime Minister== On November 2, 2013, Prime Minister [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]], who had declared his intention to quit the government following the [[Georgian presidential election, 2013|October 2013 presidential election]], named Garibashvili as his successor.{{cite news|title=Garibashvili Named as Next PM|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=26653|accessdate=November 2, 2013|newspaper=Civil Georgia|date=November 2, 2013}} He and [[Cabinet of Irakli Garibashvili|his cabinet]] won in a vote of 93-19{{cite web|title=Georgia's Parliament Approves New Prime Minister|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/georgias-parliament-approves-prime-minister-20952201|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=November 20, 2013}} in the [[Parliament of Georgia]] on November 20, 2013. Garibashvili thus occupied the most powerful political office in the country as the [[Constitution of Georgia (country)|constitution]] amendments had transferred power from the president to the prime minister and the government. At heated parliamentary debates with the [[United National Movement (Georgia)|United National Movement]] minority during the vote, Garibashvili promised economic improvement and stressed that Georgia's EU and NATO aspiration would remain his foreign priorities. On November 24, 2013, he was elected chairman of the Georgian Dream–Democratic Georgia party, succeeding Ivanishvili.[http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=26721 Ivanishvili: 'I Quit Politics, But Remain Active Citizen']. ''Civil Georgia''. November 24, 2013. Garibashvili announced his resignation on December 23, 2015.{{cite web|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=28876|title=PM Irakli Garibashvili Resigns|author=Civil.ge|date=December 23, 2015|publisher=Civil.ge|accessdate=December 23, 2015}} While no reason was given for the sudden move, it was reported that he may have done so due to low levels of support for the Georgian Dream among the populace, with it polling at 18% in November, and [[Georgian parliamentary election, 2016|parliamentary elections scheduled for 2016]].{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/georgia-pm-address-nation-coalition-discusses-replacement-141241289.html|title=Georgia prime minister resigns after two years|last=Metreveli|first=Irakli|date=December 23, 2015|publisher=Yahoo.com|accessdate=December 23, 2015}} Opposition politicians, analysts and media speculated that falling support for the ruling Georgian Dream coalition, pressure from the previous prime minister [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]], or tensions with the president [[Giorgi Margvelashvili]] were possible explanations for Garibashvili's resignation.{{cite news|last1=Fuller|first1=Liz|title=Did Georgia's 'Informal Leader' Pressure Prime Minister To Resign?|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/caucasus-report-georgia-garibashvili-resigns/27447558.html|accessdate=December 27, 2015|agency=Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty|date=December 24, 2015}} Garibashvili was succeeded as prime minister by [[Giorgi Kvirikashvili]], who had been his [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Georgia|Minister of Foreign Affairs]], with the transfer of power taking effect on December 29.{{cite web|url=http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=28892|title=Kvirikashvili Confirmed as New PM|author=Civil.ge|date=2015-12-29|publisher=Civil.ge|accessdate=2015-12-29}} ===Government initiatives=== During his tenure the Security and Crisis Management Council was established, as stipulated by the new [[Constitution of Georgia (country)|Constitution of Georgia]].{{cite web|url=http://pirweli.com.ge/index.php?menuid=8&id=53060|title=pirweli.com.ge|website=pirweli.com.ge|accessdate=March 29, 2018}} In addition, the Unified Coordination Center for Crisis Management was created, with technical assistance from the US, the United Kingdom and Israel.http://1tv.ge/news-view/60326/ To coordinate the country’s economic policy, Irakli Garibashvili established the Economic Council.http://newsport.ge/96866-ristvis-sheiqmna-premierministrtan-arsebuli-ekonomikuri-sabcho#.UsDKpNIW3AQ {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141216043101/http://newsport.ge/96866-ristvis-sheiqmna-premierministrtan-arsebuli-ekonomikuri-sabcho |date=December 16, 2014 }} ===Human rights=== The Georgian Government initiated, and the [[European Union]] directly supported, the development of the Human Rights Strategy and Action Plan.{{cite web|title=Georgia Advances in Human Rights|url=http://www.ge.undp.org/content/georgia/en/home/presscenter/pressreleases/2014/02/13/georgian-government-presents-national-strategy-and-action-plan-on-human-rights.html|website=UNDP in Georgia|accessdate=27 January 2016}} A relevant statement was made by Prime Minister Garibashvili at the Human Rights Conference, on December 4, 2013. The Human Rights Strategy covers seven years and will not depend on the political cycle.{{cite web|title=National Human Rights Strategy of Georgia|url=http://yourhumanrights.ge/about-us/national-human-rights-strategy-of-georgia/|website=Georgian Government for Your Rights|accessdate=27 January 2016|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160203001730/http://yourhumanrights.ge/about-us/national-human-rights-strategy-of-georgia/|archivedate=February 3, 2016|df=mdy-all}} ===Foreign policy=== During his tenure, Garibashvili visited the neighboring countries Armenia, Azerbaijan and Turkey, several European nations, the United States, Israel, the People's Republic of China, and participated in several international summits and forums. While relations to Russia improved, there was no state visits to and from Russia.{{cite web|title=Prime Minister's Visits and Meetings|url=http://gov.ge/index.php?lang_id=ENG&sec_id=40|publisher=Government of Georgia}} Relations to the European Union were a priority, culminating in the EU-Georgia Association Agreement, initiated at the Vilnius summit and signed on June 27, 2014. This association agreement included a deep and comprehensive free trade agreement between Georgia and the European Union and paved the way for the abolition of visa for travel from Georgia to the [[Schengen area]], planned for 2017.{{cite web|title=EU-Georgia relations|url=http://eeas.europa.eu/georgia/index_en.htm|website=European External Action Service|accessdate=April 10, 2015}}{{cite news|title=Prime Minister congratulates the Georgian people on EU’s positive conclusion regarding visa liberalization action plan|url=http://commersant.ge/index.php?m=5&news_id=30594&cat_id=7|agency=Commersant.ge|date=December 22, 2015}} ==Personal life== Garibashvili is married to Nunuka Tamazashvili (born 1983), with three sons, Nikoloz (born 2005), Andria (born 2010), Gabriel (born 2015) and one daughter Nino (born 2016). {{cite web|title=Asset Declaration|url=https://declaration.gov.ge/eng/declaration.php?id=44067|publisher=Government of Georgia|accessdate=December 24, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151225052231/https://declaration.gov.ge/eng/declaration.php?id=44067|archivedate=December 25, 2015|df=mdy-all}}{{cite news|title=Third son born to Georgian PM’s family|url=http://en.trend.az/scaucasus/georgia/2381349.html|accessdate=December 24, 2015|agency=Trend.az}} His father-in-law, Tamaz Tamazashvili, is a former police general who was arrested on charges of illegally carrying and keeping weapon and explosives in October 2011. Garibashvili, a member of then-opposition Georgian Dream party, claimed the arrest was politically motivated. After the Georgian Dream acceded to power in October 2012, Tamazashvili was released from prison.{{cite news|title="Political Motives of General Tamaz Tamazashvili's Imprisonment Was Doubtlessly Proved"|url=http://www.humanrights.ge/index.php?a=main&pid=16968&lang=eng|accessdate=November 20, 2013|newspaper=Humanrights.ge|date=August 16, 2013|agency=PirWeli Information Agency}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commonscategory|Irakli Gharibashvili|Irakli Garibashvili}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150520222212/http://irakligaribashvili.ge/ Official Website] * [https://m.youtube.com/channel/UChye7mXi6iOQN9tV-zZ_S1Q Irakli Gharibashvili] on Youtube {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Bidzina Ivanishvili]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Prime Minister of Georgia]]|years=2013–2015}} {{s-aft|after={{nowrap|[[Giorgi Kvirikashvili]]}}}} {{s-end}} {{Prime Ministers of Georgia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Garibashvili, Irakli}} [[Category:Prime Ministers of Georgia]] [[Category:1982 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Georgia (country)]] [[Category:Government ministers of Georgia (country)]] [[Category:People from Tbilisi]] [[Category:Tbilisi State University alumni]] [[Category:University of Paris alumni]] [[Category:21st-century politicians from Georgia (country)]]

{{Infobox person | name =John Berry McFerrin | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = July 15, 1807 | birth_place = [[Rutherford County, Tennessee]], U.S. | death_date = 1887 | death_place = [[Davidson County, Tennessee]], U.S. | death_cause = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation =Preacher | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | spouse = A. A. Probart
Cynthia T. McGavock | children =8 | relatives = [[John McGavock]] (father-in-law)
[[James Henderson Berry]] (second nephew)
[[Campbell Polson Berry]] (second nephew) | box_width = }} '''John Berry McFerrin''' (1807–1887) was an American [[Methodist Episcopal Church, South|Methodist]] preacher and editor. He served as a chaplain in the [[Confederate States Army]] during the [[American Civil War]]. ==Early life== John Berry McFerrin was born on July 15, 1807 in [[Rutherford County, Tennessee]].William S. Speer, ''Sketches of Prominent Tennesseans: Containing Biographies and Records of Many of the Families who Have Attained Prominence in Tennessee'', Genealogical Publishing Com, 2010, pp. 359–361 [https://books.google.com/books?id=UsVGPmfzJRYC&dq=%22John+B.+McFerrin%22&source=gbs_navlinks_s] His paternal great-grandfather, William McFerrin, Sr., emigrated to [[York County, Pennsylvania]] from Ireland in 1730. His paternal grandfather, William McFerrin, Jr., served in the [[American Revolutionary War]] of 1775-1783, including at the [[Battle of Kings Mountain]] in 1780. His maternal great-grandfather, James Laughlin, emigrated to the United States from [[Belfast]]. His father, James McFerrin, was born in [[Washington County, Virginia]] and served as a Methodist pastor in [[Bellefonte, Alabama]].Anson West, ''A History of Methodism in Alabama'', Nashville, Tennessee: Publishing House of the M.E. South, 1803, pp. 195-196 [https://books.google.com/books?id=3zbTAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA196] His mother, Jane Campbell Berry, was also born in Washington County, Virginia. McFerrin grew up on a farm. ==Career== McFerrin started preaching in 1825 and became an ordained Methodist preacher in 1829. He delivered his first sermon in [[Tuscumbia, Alabama]] His other sermons were delivered in [[Franklin County, Alabama]], [[Lawrence County, Alabama]] and [[Limestone County, Alabama]]. He then served as a missionary, converting Native Americans to Christianity.Christopher H. Owen, ''The Sacred Flame of Love: Methodism and Society in Nineteenth-century Georgia'', Athens, Georgia: University of Georgia Press, 1998, p. 109 [https://books.google.com/books?id=GtcQAMeVw7IC&pg=PA109] Later, he preached in [[Huntsville, Alabama]], [[Pulaski, Tennessee]], and in [[Nashville]], Tennessee. He then became a presiding elder in [[Florence, Alabama]] and in [[Cumberland County, Tennessee]]. He became the pastor at [[McKendree United Methodist Church]] in Nashville.Henry Thurston Tipps, ''A History of McKendree Church'', Nashville, Tennessee: Parthenon Press, 1984 p. 140 In the 1830s, he was one of the leaders of the [[Temperance movement in the United States|temperance movement]] in Tennessee.Joe Coker, ''Liquor in the Land of the Lost Cause: Southern White Evangelicals and the Prohibition Movement'', Louisville, Kentucky: University Press of Kentucky, 2007, p. 26 [https://books.google.com/books?id=SGVZuyHe1r0C&pg=PA26] When President [[James K. Polk]] (1795-1849) became ill, he converted him from Presbyterian to Methodist.John McCollister, ''God and the Oval Office: The Religious Faith of Our 43 Presidents'', Nashville, Tennessee: Thomas Nelson, 2005 [https://books.google.com/books?id=MkOErWeC1G4C&pg=PT48] He later conducted his funeral service. He also converted [[John Ross (Cherokee chief)|John Ross]] (1790–1866), who served as the [[Principal Chiefs of the Cherokee|Principal Chief]] of the [[Cherokee Nation (19th century)|Cherokee Nation]] from 1828 to 1866.Gary E. Moulton, ''John Ross, Cherokee Chief'', Athens, Georgia: University of Georgia Press, 1978, p. 107 [https://books.google.com/books?id=-rXWgUGRvbQC&pg=PA7] McFerrin was one of the early founders of La Grange College in Alabama, later known as the [[University of North Alabama]] in Florence, Alabama. As a result, he was honored by La Grange College with an honorary Doctorate in 1847. He also received an honorary Doctorate from [[Randolph–Macon College]] in [[Ashland, Virginia]], also in 1847. During the [[American Civil War]] of 1861 to 1865, McFerrin served as a Methodist chaplain in the [[Confederate States Army]], converting soldiers to the Methodist Church.[http://tn.gov/tsla/cwsb/1863-06-Article-120-Page165.pdf Kidnapping Slaves] Specifically, he served in the [[Second Corps, Army of Tennessee|Second Corps]] of the Confederate [[Army of Tennessee]], under General [[Joseph E. Johnston]] (1807–1891).John Wesley Brinsfield, ''The Spirit Divided: Memoirs of Civil War Chaplains: the Confederacy'', Macon, Georgia: Mercer University Press, 2006, pp. 245-246 [https://books.google.com/books?id=Xk4ykJ4Lr1sC&pg=PA245] Indeed, he was a proponent of the [[Slavery in the United States|slavery]] of African-Americans in the United States.Larry E. Tise, ''Proslavery: A History of the Defense of Slavery in America, 1701-1840'', Athens, Georgia: University of Georgia Press, 1990, p. 415 [https://books.google.com/books?id=JvWA08GsAAwC&pg=PA415] However, his religious service during the war was not without controversy. In a letter to Governor [[Andrew Johnson]] (1808–1875) on April 22, 1862, Presbyterian lawyer [[Adrian Van Sinderen Lindsley]] (1814-1885) blamed him for encouraging secessionist activities in Nashville, as opposed to more moderate Methodists like Reverend [[Holland Nimmons McTyeire]] (1824–1889), Reverend [[John B. Somers]] (1801-1876), Reverend [[James L. Houston]] (1806-1888) and [[Alexander Little Page Green]] (1806-1874).Andrew Johnson, ''The Papers: 1822-1851'', Knoxville, Tennessee: University of Tennessee Press, Volume 5, p. 320 [https://books.google.com/books?id=-pWn6WXtgiwC&pg=PA320] He was also accused of trying to kidnap freed slaves, in an attempt to retrieve his lost slaves. He eventually surrendered, as the Confederate cause was lost. His estate was ruined by 1865. McFerrin was a prolific editor of Methodist publications. He served as the editor of the ''[[Nashville Christian Advocate|Southwestern Christian Advocate]]'' from 1840 to 1844 and the ''Christian Advocate'' from 1855 to 1858. Shortly after the war, from 1869 to 1873, he edited the three-volume ''History of Methodism in Tennessee''. He went on to serve as the manager of the Methodist Publishing House from 1878 to 1887.John E. Fisher, ''They Rode with Forrest and Wheeler: A Chronicle of Five Tennessee Brothers' Service in the Confederate Western Cavalry'', Jefferson, North Carolina: McFarland & Company, 1995, p. 83 [https://books.google.com/books?id=mrZPp4gJOPcC&pg=PA83] In September 1881, McFerrin attended an Ecumenical Conference in London, England as a delegate of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South. During that trip, he conducted services not only in London, but also in Edinburgh, Dublin, Paris and Newcastle. ==Personal life== McFerrin was married twice. McFerrin married A. A. Probart of Nashville, daughter of William Y. Probart and Sarah Probart, on September 18, 1833. They had five children: *Sarah Jane McFerrin. *James William McFerrin. *John A. McFerrin. *Elizabeth Johnston McFerrin. *Almira Probart McFerrin. She died in May 1854. McFerrin remarried, to Cynthia T. McGavock of Nashville, daughter of [[John McGavock]] and Elizabeth McGavock. They had three children: *Kitty Lou McFerrin. *Mary McGinty McFerrin. *Elizabeth McGavock McFerrin. McFerrin was also a second cousin of James McFerrin Berry, father of [[James Henderson Berry]] (1841-1913), the 14th Governor of Arkansas, and to B.H. Berry, father of [[Campbell Polson Berry]] (1834-1901), a Congressman from California. ==Death and legacy== McFerrin died in 1887 in [[Davidson County, Tennessee]]. The neighborhood of ''McFerrin Park'', together with the public park called ''McFerrin Park'', both located in Northeastern Nashville, are named in his honor.Christine Kreyling, [http://www.sitemason.com/files/lHsgSI/PON_Neighborhoods_Northeast.pdf Nashville and Its Neighborhood: Fanning the Flames of Place] It was developed on the farmland formerly owned by him. ==Bibliography== ===Primary source=== *John Berry McFerrin (ed.), ''History of Methodism in Tennessee'' (Nashville, Tennessee: Publishing House of the M.E. South, 1888).[https://books.google.com/books/about/History_of_Methodism_in_Tennessee.html?id=gVmtum-wESYC&redir_esc=y Google Books] ===Secondary source=== *[[Oscar Penn Fitzgerald]], ''John B. McFerrin: A Biography'' (Nashville, Tennessee: Publishing House of the M.E. South, 1888).[https://books.google.com/books?id=DUlCAAAAIAAJ&oe=UTF-8&redir_esc=y Google Books] *[[William McFerrin Stowe]], ''John B. McFerrin, Editorial Contraversialist, 1840-1858'' (Durham, North Carolina: Duke University Press, 1935).[https://books.google.com/books?id=I6kOywAACAAJ&dq=%22John+B.+McFerrin%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ehw3U8HpKY3ylAW3yICwCQ&ved=0CCwQ6AEwADgK Google Books] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:McFerrin, John Berry}} [[Category:1807 births]] [[Category:1887 deaths]] [[Category:People from Rutherford County, Tennessee]] [[Category:People from Davidson County, Tennessee]] [[Category:American people of Irish descent]] [[Category:American Methodist clergy]] [[Category:American Methodist missionaries]] [[Category:Confederate States Army chaplains]] [[Category:19th-century American newspaper editors]] [[Category:American temperance activists]] [[Category:American proslavery activists]] [[Category:James K. Polk]] [[Category:19th-century American journalists]] [[Category:Southern Methodists]] [[Category:McGavock family]] [[Category:American male journalists]] [[Category:Methodist missionaries in the United States]]

{{BLP sources|date=January 2012}} '''Jorien van den Herik''' (born 11 November 1943 in [[Sliedrecht]]) is a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] business man and was [[chairman]] of [[Feyenoord Rotterdam]] till 2006.
Van den Herik helped Feyenoord to purchase some players in 1984 as chairman of the "Friends of Feyenoord Group". In a few years time he had invested 3 million [[Dutch gulden]]s in the club. In 1989 be became president of the [[Feijenoord Stadion|Stadion Feyenoord NV]]. When Feyenoord almost was bankrupt due to their sponsor [[HCS Technologies|HCS]], Van den Herik claimed his position in the Feyenoord board by saying "If I lose my money, I would like to be there myself".{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} In 1992, he became Feyenoord's chairman by taking over from {{Interlanguage link multi|Amandus Lundqvist|nl}}.
In 1998 the Fiscal Intelligence and Investigation Service ([[FIOD-ECD|FIOD]]) visited Feyenoord because of suspected fraud.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} Mainly based on the signings of [[Aurelio Vidmar]], [[Christian Gyan]] and [[Patrick Allotey]].{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} This became a continuous subject in the years to come with Van den Herik as the main suspect.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} After several visits in court Van den Herik and Feyenoord were found to be not guilty in 2002.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} The Attorney General however appealed, but in 2005, after three years of investigations the results stayed the same.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} They still did not give up and went into cassation.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} On 19 December 2006 Van den Herik and Feyenoord came out of court as the winners again and this time it was the final decision.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} Van den Herik has already said he will take the Attorney General to court to reclaim the damage his personality has received in all these years.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}}
The 2005/06 season ended in deception for Feyenoord.{{clarify|date=January 2012}} The team was challenging the Dutch Championship for most of the season, but eventually lost it to [[PSV Eindhoven]]. The newly born Dutch play-offs (held for the first time that year) then became fatal for Feyenoord. [[Ajax Amsterdam]] which ended on a fair distance in the regular league was Feyenoord's opponent in the play-offs and overclassed them and Feyenoord was eliminated for winning an [[UEFA Champions League]] ticket. During the summer break Feyenoord had to sell two of their key players, [[Salomon Kalou]] and the very popular [[Dirk Kuyt]]. Only a small amount of the money became available to invest in new players.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} When [[Angelos Charisteas]] was signed from arch rivals Ajax to replace Dirk Kuyt hundreds of die-hard fans moved to the Feyenoord board to force Van den Herik to resign. Van den Herik stayed at the team and did not want to give up his position, unless the growing pressure, the underperforming of the team and several other problems that had not been solved yet.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} In the meanwhile Feyenoord was placed under special guardianship because of their financial problems.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}} A group of some Feyenoord icons, with former chairman [[Gerard Kerkum]] as their leader, operated under the name of "Commissie Kerkum" to restructure Feyenoord's future. In December 2006 they published their thoughts and came to the conclusion that Van den Herik should leave the club. Still Van den Herik did not want to leave, however after hooligan incidents in [[Nancy, France|Nancy]] and the growing pressure he announced his retirement in mid December. Van den Herik himself said not the thoughts of the Commissie Kerkum were the key factor for his decision, but the upcoming final result in the fraud case was. After the case was finished in December 2006 - Van den Herik was acquitted - he stepped down.{{citation needed|date=January 2012}}
In the summer transfer window of 2007, Feyenoord surprised friend and foe with the signing of big names like Roy Makaay and Giovanni van Bronckhorst. According to player manager Rob Jansen, Van den Herik played an important role in the realization of the transfers.<ref>{{cite web |author=Chris van Nijnatten |year=2006 |url=http://www.ad.nl/sport/article1473578.ece |title=Het succes van Feyenoord |publisher= Ad.nl}}</ref>
==Feyenoord's honours under Jorien van den Herik== * [[Eredivisie|Eredivisie Championships]]: ** 1993, 1999 * [[KNVB Cup]]s: **1992, 1994, 1995 * [[Johan Cruijff-schaal|Supercup]]: **1999 * [[UEFA Cup]]: **2002
<!-- English style, see Wikipedia:Categorization of people -->
==References== <references />

{{Infobox company |name = KMW+Nexter Defense Systems N.V. |logo = Logo-KNDS.jpg |logo_size = 230px |logo_alt = |logo_caption = |type = [[Naamloze vennootschap]] |industry = [[Arms industry|Defence]] |founded = {{start date and age|2015|12|15}} | hq_location_city = [[Amsterdam]] | hq_location_country = [[Netherlands]] |area_served = |key_people = [[Margaret Hill (businessman)|Margaret Hill]] ([[Managing Director]]) |products = |services = |revenue = |revenue_year = |operating_income = |income_year = |net_income = |net_income_year = |assets = |assets_year = |equity = |equity_year = |owner = |num_employees = >6,000 |num_employees_year = |subsid = [[Krauss-Maffei Wegmann]]
[[Nexter Systems]] |divisions = |homepage = [http://www.knds.com www.knds.com] |footnotes = |inti = }} The '''KMW+Nexter Defense Systems''' ('''KNDS''') is a European defence industry holding company, which is result for merger between [[Krauss-Maffei Wegmann]] and [[Nexter Systems]] under KANT project. ==KANT project== The KANT project is [[joint venture]] completed by the [[Germany|German]] family-controlled defence company Krauss-Maffei Wegmann and [[France|French]] government-owned [[weapons manufacturer|armoured platform manufacturer]] Nexter Systems. The merger was completed 15 December 2015. The joint holding company is based in [[Leiden]], [[Netherlands]]. KANT is an acronym of "KMW And Nexter Together."[http://defense-update.com/20151215_kant.html KMW, Nexter Merger Completed]. defense-update.com. Retrieved 10 June 2016 Krauss-Maffei Wegmann manufactures tanks, Nexter makes artillery.[http://www.upi.com/Business_News/Security-Industry/2015/05/27/Report-KMW-Nexter-to-sign-merger-agreement/3781432755336/ Report: KMW, Nexter to sign merger agreement]. upi.com. Retrieved 13 June 2015 On 29 July 2015 the merger between the two companies has been officially finalized in [[Paris]].[http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/german-french-tank-makers-kmw-and-nexter-seal-armoured-vehicles-tie-up/articleshow/48252184.cms German, French tank makers KMW and Nexter seal armoured vehicles tie-up]. economictimes.indiatimes.com, retrieved 27 July 2015 ==History== There was a hearing at the [[National Assembly (France)]] for this joint venture and both CEO's explained how this project could boost both tank manufacturers avoiding export restrictions, especially in Germany.[http://www.assemblee-nationale.fr/14/cr-cdef/14-15/c1415030.asp Commission de la défense nationale et des forces armées]. assemblee-nationale.fr. Retrieved 13 June 2015 (French) Support for a deal has been building in both countries' capitals. In July 2015 French lawmakers pushed through a measure that permits the privatization of state-owned defense companies, paving the way for KMW and Nexter to join forces.[http://www.dw.com/en/german-french-tank-makers-could-merge-next-week/a-18575135 German, French tank makers could merge next week]. dw.com, 10 July 2015 ==Products== In June 2018 Germany and France signed a letter of intent for KNDS to develop Main Combat Ground System, a common main battle tank, and Common Indirect Fire System, a common 155mm self-propelled artillery gun.https://defpost.com/kmw-nexter-join-forces-main-ground-combat-system-common-indirect-fire-system/ ===Leopard 2 upgrade=== One of KNDS's first projects is [[Leopard_2#Further_improvements|upgrading the Leopard 2]], with a focus on increasing effectiveness against contemporary threats like the [[ATGM]] and the Russian [[T-14 Armata]].[http://www.dw.com/en/german-french-tank-makers-could-merge-next-week/a-18575135 German, French tank makers could merge next week]. dw.com, 10 July 2015 ===European Main Battle Tank=== At [[Eurosatory]] military trade fair, June 11-15 2018 in Paris, France, KNDS unveiled the "European Main Battle Tank" (EMBT), a technology demonstration [[main battle tank]] that combines the hull of a [[Leopard 2A7]] with the lighter, two-man turret of a [[Leclerc]].{{cite web |last1=Peck |first1=Michael |title=European Main Battle Tank: France and Germany's New Joint Super Weapon? |url=https://nationalinterest.org/blog/buzz/european-main-battle-tank-france-and-germanys-new-joint-super-weapon-25017 |website=The National Interest |accessdate=22 July 2018 |language=en |date=4 July 2018}} ===Main Combat Ground System=== {{main|Main Ground Combat System}} ===Common Indirect Fire System=== Common Indirect Fire System (CIFS) is a French-German program to develop a [[155mm]] [[self-propelled artillery]] gun. Introduction of the CIFS is scheduled for 2040. == Notes == == External links == * {{Official website|http://www.knds.com}} * [http://www.kmweg.com Krauss-Maffei Wegmann website] * [http://www.nexter-group.com Nexter Group website] {{KMW+Nexter Defense Systems}} [[Category:Military industry]]

'''Land administration''' is the way in which the rules of [[land tenure]] are applied and made operational. Land administration, whether formal or informal, comprises an extensive range of systems and processes to administer.<ref>[http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/005/Y4307E/y4307e05.htm#bm05.2 Land Tenure and Rural Development, FAO Land Tenure Studies, No 3, Rome, 2002. - 3.16 Land administration]</ref> The processes of land administration include the transfer of rights in land from one party to another through sale, lease, loan, gift and inheritance; the regulating of land and property development; the use and conservation of the land; the gathering of revenues from the land through sales, leasing, and taxation; and the resolving of conflicts concerning the ownership and the use of land. Land administration functions may be divided into four components: Juridical, regulatory, fiscal, and information management. These functions of land administration may be organized in terms of agencies responsible for [[National mapping agency|surveying and mapping]], [[land registration]], and [[Land valuation#Governing authorities and professional organizations|land valuation]].<ref>Dale & McLaughlin (1999) Land Administration. Oxford University Press, p. 10</ref> The purpose and scope of this knowledge domain appear from the following introducing notes: :These Guidelines define land administration as the process whereby land and the information about land may be effectively managed. They are mainly written for senior governmental staff and politicians engaged in land administration issues. The aim is to outline the benefit of having a relevant and reliable land information system in place. The Guidelines identify the factors that should be taken into account in developing the legislation, organization, databases and maps, as well as the funding mechanisms, required to implement and maintain a solid land administration system.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.unece.org/index.php?id=25632 |title=Land Administration Guidelines With Special Reference to Countries in Transition |publisher=United Nations Economic Commission for Europe |date=December 1996}}</ref>
An early example of use of the notion of land administration is a 1973 ''Seminar on Land Administration'' in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.<ref>Dale & McLaughlin (1988) Land Information Management. - An introduction with special reference to cadastral problems in Third World countries. Clarendon Press, Oxford, p. 18, note 17</ref> ''Land administration arrangements'' were charted in a 1985 paper by Holstein, McLaughlin, and Nichols,<ref>Dale & McLaughlin (1988) p. 18, note 10</ref> and the Department of Lands and Surveys, Western Australia changed name in 1986 to Department of Land Administration.<ref>[[Department of Lands and Surveys, Western Australia]]</ref> The UNECE in 1996 published ''Land Administration Guidelines With Special Reference to Countries in Transition'',<ref>[http://www.unece.org/index.php?id=25632 Land Administration Guidelines With Special Reference to Countries in Transition. December 1996.] {{ISBN|92-1-116644-6}}</ref> and the Dale & McLaughlin textbook on ''Land Information Management'' from 1988 was in 1999 succeeded by the textbook ''Land Administration''.
== History ==
The practise of land administration is older than the presently used term. In ''The Cadastral Map in the Service of the State'', mention is made of [[Cadastre|cadastral survey]] and subsequent tax collection in northern part of the Netherlands, initiated by an order in 1533.<ref>Roger J P Kain & Elizabeth Baigent (1992) The Cadastral Map in the Service of the State - A history of property mapping. The University of Chicago press. p. 13</ref> Other early, seventeenth century mapping for administrative purposes are found, e.g. in Sweden and in German [[Principality|principalities]]. In the duchy of Austrian Lombardy, a complete cadastral survey, the Milan cadaster, was finally adopted as a taxation base in 1760, and this provided the model for continental European countries to follow.<ref>Kain & Baigent (1992), p. 184-185</ref> Largely independent from this cadastral development, local courts recorded [[Deed#Deeds of conveyance|deeds of conveyance]]. In the context of [[Codification (law)|codification]] of national legislation, most European countries in the nineteenth century established a [[Torrens title|title system]] at the local courts. England and Wales departed from this trend, as prolonged debates during the nineteenth century left parties with optional public recording of deeds of conveyance and the locating of properties and their boundaries on large-scale topographic maps, where available, similar to the [[metes and bounds]] method.<ref>Kain & Baigent (1992), p. 256, 275</ref> However, most of [[British Raj|British India]] was covered, during the nineteenth century, by the Revenue Survey.<ref>Kain & Baigent (1992), p. 325 f</ref>
In the colony (now state) of South Australia, [[Robert Torrens]] in 1858 introduced a title system. Like the Milan cadastre, this system became a model to be followed, initially within the [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]]. In the USA, the [[Land Ordinance of 1785]] established the basis for the [[Public Land Survey System]], which provides locational functions as the cadastral or - in modern terms - [[land information system]] described above. For the present adoption of the Torrens system in the USA, see Justin T. Holl, Jr. et al. (2007).<ref>[http://grm.thomsonreuters.com/our-knowledge/2011/07/2011/12/2011/12/white-paper-the-earthen-vessel-land-records-in-the-united-states.aspx Justin T. Holl, Jr., Peter Rabley, Mark Monacelli, David Ewan (2007) The Earthen Vessel - Land Records in the United States. White paper, posted December 16, 2011. Thomson Reuters. 29 pages]</ref>
== International organizations == The domain of '''land administration''' is characterized by the engagement of [[international organization]]s as much as by its intrinsic, multi-disciplinary structure. Among [[intergovernmental organization]]s, * The [[World Bank]] has supported land and real estate reforms across a wide range of countries.<ref>[http://go.worldbank.org/A6S3NQ9PZ0 Galal, A; Razzaz, Omar (2001) Reforming land and real estate markets. WPS2616.]</ref> Its Agriculture and Rural Development research program includes the development of the Land Governance Assessment Framework (LGAF)<ref>[http://go.worldbank.org/4ROUS8GZG0 Land Governance Assessment Framework (LGAF)]</ref> and the issuing of Policy Research Reports like ''Land Policies for Growth and Poverty Reduction (2003)''.<ref>[http://go.worldbank.org/NTEKMMPRP0 Policy Research Report: Land Policies for Growth and Poverty Reduction (2003)]</ref> Moreover, the World Bank Group offer a yearly study of conditions for private sector development, including a rating of the ease of ''Registering property''.<ref>[http://www.doingbusiness.org/data/exploretopics/registering-property Registering Property]</ref> * [[UN-HABITAT]]'s section on Land, Tenure & Property Administration focus on the implementation of land, housing and property rights, particularly women's secure tenure, affordable land management systems and pro-poor flexible types of tenure. The insufficient attention paid to the development of methods for implementing land policies, led to the development of pro poor land tools that are affordable and accessible for use by a variety of stakeholders.<ref>[http://www.unhabitat.org/content.asp?typeid=19&catid=283&cid=1504 UN-HABITAT, Land & Housing, Research & Tool Development] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119072839/http://www.unhabitat.org/content.asp?typeid=19&catid=283&cid=1504 |date=2012-01-19 }}</ref> Efforts further include the creation of the Global Land Tool Network (GLTN).<ref>[http://www.gltn.net/ The Global Land Tool Network (GLTN)]</ref> * [[FAO]] focuses on [[land tenure]] in the rural domain,<ref>[http://www.fao.org/nr/tenure/lt-home/en/?no_cache=1 Access and Tenure of Natural Resources]</ref> and has among others issued a ''Multilingual thesaurus on land tenure''.<ref>[http://www.fao.org/sd/2003/in0602_en.htm Multilingual land tenure thesaurus]</ref> * The [[European Commission]] through its [[EuropeAid|Development and Cooperation - EuropeAid]] supports agriculture and rural development,<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/what/rural-development/index_en.htm European Commission > EuropeAid > ..Agriculture & rural development] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111231151036/http://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/what/rural-development/index_en.htm |date=2011-12-31 }}</ref> including a more secure access to land <ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/development/icenter/repository/EU_Land_Guidelines_Final_12_2004_en.pdf EU Land Guidelines, 2004] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111026161609/http://ec.europa.eu/development/icenter/repository/EU_Land_Guidelines_Final_12_2004_en.pdf |date=2011-10-26 }}</ref>
International professional associations include * The [[International Federation of Surveyors]] with its 10 commissions, including ''7. Cadastre and Land Management'',<ref>[http://www.fig.net/comm/comindex.htm FIG Commissions]</ref> and the repository of pertinent articles, OICRF<ref>[http://www.oicrf.org/ Office International du Cadastre et du Régime Foncier (OICRF)]</ref> * Commonwealth Association of Surveying and Land Economy (CASLE), with its international journal ''Survey Review''<ref>[http://www.casle.org/ The Commonwealth Association of Surveying and Land Economy]</ref> * The International Union of [[Civil law notary|Notaries]], which issues the international journal ''Notarius International''<ref>[http://uinl.net/publicaciones.asp?idioma=ing&submenu=NOTARIUS The International Union of Notaries (U.I.N.L.), Notarius International]</ref>
The list of partners in the ''Global Land Tool Network'' refers to more international organisations, [[NGO]]s, research institutions, etc.<ref>[http://www.gltn.net/images/stories/list_of_partners-as_of_june11.pdf Global Land Tool Network, Partner list, June 2011]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== University departments ==
The Faculty of Geo-Information Science and Earth Observation (ITC) of the University of Twente, the Netherlands, provides international postgraduate education, research and project services in the field of geo-information science and earth observation using remote sensing and GIS. The aim of ITC's activities is the international exchange of knowledge, focusing on capacity building and institutional development in developing countries and emerging economies. ITC cooperates with the United Nations University at developing and carrying out a joint programme on capacity building in disaster management and in land administration<ref>[http://www.itc.nl/unu-las UNU School for Land Administration Studies]</ref> * [http://www.itc.nl/Pub/study/Course-domains/Land-administration Land Administration]
[[Geomatics]] at the University of Melbourne, Australia, is about science and research into spatial information. The Geomatics team is an international leader in spatial data infrastructures and land administration. The research agenda embraces legal, institutional and technical issues of establishing and accessing information about land faced by land managers and administrators, in both developed and developing countries. * [http://www.csdila.unimelb.edu.au/ Centre for Spatial Data Infrastructures and Land Administration]
A number of universities offer land administration courses in the context of related master's degree programmes: * [http://www.landentwicklung-muenchen.de/master/ Technische Universität München (TUM), Germany: Land Management and Land Tenure] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20111230161603/http://www.kth.se/en/studies/programmes/master/programmes/be/realestate/master-s-programme-in-real-estate-development-and-financial-services-1.48568 KTH Royal Institute of Technology, Stockholm, Sweden: Real Estate Development and Financial Services] * [https://archive.is/20130101070420/http://www.geomatics.ucalgary.ca/specializations Department of Geomatics Engineering, University of Calgary, Canada: GIS and Land Tenure] * [http://intranet.cpa.zju.edu.cn/show.aspx?id=1457&cid=73 Public Administration College of Zhejiang University: Land Resources Management] *[http://www.utm.my/academicprogrammes/listings/master-of-science-in-land-administration-development/ Faculty of Geoinformation & Real Estate, Universiti Teknologi Malaysia (UTM): Land Administration and Development]
== See also == * [[Cadastre]] * [[Land reform]] * [[Land registration]] * [[Land tenure]]
== References == <references />

page.title: List of business schools in the United States

revision.text:
This is a '''list of business schools in the United States'''. Business schools are listed in alphabetical order by state, then name. Schools named after people are alphabetized by last name. Accreditation bodies for business schools in the United States include [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]] (AACSB), [[Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs]] (ACBSP), and [[International Assembly for Collegiate Business Education]] (IACBE). This list is sortable. Click on the boxes next to the attribute names to sort the list by state, school, parent university, etc. {{dynamic list}} {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! State ! School ! {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{infobox person | name = Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1906|08|21}} | birth_place = [[Enghien-les-Bains]], France | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1996|04|11|1906|08|21}} | death_place = Paris, France | nationality = French | occupation = founder of [[publicis]] | relatives = [[Élisabeth Badinter]] <small>(daughter)</small> }} '''Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet''' (21 August 1906 – 11 April 1996) was a French advertising magnate best known as the founder of [[Publicis Groupe]]. Bleustein-Blanchet also invented radio advertising in France, helped create the first French opinion polls, introduced [[Édith Piaf]] to the French public, and fought with the [[Free French]] forces during World War II.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1996/04/13/world/marcel-bleustein-blanchet-dies-paris-advertising-giant-was-89.html Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet Dies; Paris Advertising Giant Was 89]. ''The New York Times'' (13 April 1996). Retrieved 17 August 2011.</ref> <ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituaries-marcel-bleusteinblanchet-1304631.html Obituaries: Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet – People, News]. ''The Independent''. Retrieved 17 August 2011.</ref>
The son of Abraham Bleustein, a Russian-Jewish furniture salesman in northern Paris, Marcel Bleustein left school at the age of 14 to help out in the family furniture business. He founded Publicis in 1926 in a small apartment above a butcher's shop. In 1935, he purchased Radio LL from the radio manufacturer [[Lucien Lévy]]. He renamed it Radio Cité, and introduced France's first news broadcasts as well as its first radio jingles. Radio Cité also helped launch singer [[Édith Piaf]].
In 1939, Marcel Bleustein married Sophie Vaillant, an English teacher who was the granddaughter of [[Edouard Vaillant]], a well-known 19th century Socialist politician. They had three daughters, including [[Elisabeth Badinter]], a prominent feminist writer and philosopher who chairs the supervisory board of Publicis Groupe. When the Second World War broke out, Marcel Bleustein's companies were confiscated by the German occupation forces as "Jewish properties". He joined the Resistance, took the code-name Blanchet, and was detached to serve as a co-pilot for the US [[Eighth Air Force]], flying bombing missions over France and Holland. When the war ended, he rebuilt Publicis from scratch, introducing the first opinion polls in France and developing the then-American fields of consumer research and brand analysis. [http://2.262.00515.X]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} He retained his Resistance name of Blanchet, adding it legally to his original name. After the war, Mr. Bleustein-Blanchet reopened Publicis and, calling them on the phone himself, rapidly regained old and new clients, notably Shell, Colgate-Palmolive, L'oreal, Renault, Dim and many others. In 1957 he opened the first "Publicis Drugstore" on the ground level of Publicis' headquarters, 133 avenue des Champs Elysées, former location of the Astoria hotel. The "Drugstore" was a huge success and immediately became the rendez vous point of the cool parisian youth.
During the 1970s, under the leadership of Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet and his successor, [[Maurice Lévy (Publicis)|Maurice Lévy]], Publicis became an international communications group and is now the third largest communications group in the world.<ref>[http://adage.com/article/global-news/publicis-quarter-organic-revenue-growth-7-1/145176/ Publicis' Second-Quarter Organic Revenue Growth Is 7.1%]. ''Advertising Age'' (29 July 2010). Retrieved 17 August 2011.</ref> In 2008, twelve years after his death, the [[American Advertising Federation]] announced that Marcel Bleustein-Blanchet would become the first non-American to be named to the [[Advertising Hall of Fame]].

''La rage de convaincre'' (Éditions Roberf Laffont, 1970) **Bleustein-Blanchet, Marcel. ''Les ondes de la liberté: sur mon antenne, 1934–1984'' (JC Lattès, 1984)

{{BLP sources|date=August 2012}}
{{Infobox person | name = Martua Sitorus | image = Martua Sitorus.jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = Martua Sitorus, February 2000 | birth_date = 6/2/1960 | birth_place = Pematang Siantar, Sumatera Utara | nationality = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Co-Founder, Non Executive Director (since April 2017) of [[Wilmar International]]<ref>https://www.forbes.com/profile/martua-sitorus/?list=billionaires</ref> | networth = {{gain}} US$ 1.42 Billion (04 August 2017) | spouse = Rosa Taniasuri Ong | children = 5 | parents = | known_for = Indonesia's 13th wealthiest people (Aug 2017), 1650th world (Aug 2017) }}
'''Martua Sitorus''' (born 1960), also known as '''Thio Seng Hap''' (吴笙福), initially 吴声福 is a [[Chinese Indonesian]] businessman. He was once known as the fourth richest person in Indonesia (and #377 in the world), but had decreased to fifteenth by November 2013,<ref>{{cite news|title=Indonesia's 40 richest people|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/martua-sitorus/|accessdate=23 June 2014|newspaper=Forbes}}</ref> according to [[Forbes]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Martua Sitorus|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/martua-sitorus/|accessdate=8 August 2012|newspaper=Forbes}}</ref> He and his partner, [[Kuok Khoon Hong]] founded [[Wilmar International]], the largest palm oil producer in the world.
Wilmar's business activities include oil palm [[Horticulture|cultivation]], [[oilseeds]] crushing, [[edible oils]] refining, sugar milling and refining, specialty fats, [[oleochemicals]], [[biodiesel]] and [[fertilizers]] manufacturing and grains processing. It has over 300 manufacturing plants and an extensive distribution network covering [[China]], [[India]], [[Indonesia]], [[United States]] and some 50 other countries.<ref>http://www.wilmarinternational.com/about_index.html</ref>
==Personal life==
Martua was born in [[Pematang Siantar]], a town located in [[North Sumatra]], Indonesia. After finishing high school, he continued to the University of HKBP Nomensen, [[Medan]] which was the largest city in North Sumatera to finish his economic degrees. During his teenager, Martua traded [[fish]], when grown up he started his business as a [[palm oil]] and [[mesocarp]] trader.
==Career==
===Wilmar International===
Martua along with [[Kuok Khoon Hong]], the nephew of Malaysia's richest tycoon [[Robert Kuok]], founded [[Wilmar International]] Limited and by 1991 he owned 7.100 hectare of [[palm tree]] plantations, and also build his own palm oil refinery in North Sumatra. The [[Wilmar International]] business has grown rapidly; by 2013 Wilmar owns more than 50 other companies with 300 manufacturing plants around the world.<ref>{{cite news|title=Dari batak jadi terkaya di dunia|url= http://bisnis.vivanews.com/news/read/39874-dari_batak_jadi_terkaya_di_dunia|accessdate=31 January 2013}}</ref> Martua also owns London skycraper [[Aviva Tower]] and a hospital in Medan, [[Murni Teguh Memorial Hospital]], which is named after Martua's mother, Murni Teguh. The hospital was launched on 12 December 2012 (12/12/2012).<ref>{{cite news|title=Murni Teguh Memorial Hospital|url=http://www.rsmurniteguh.com/index.php/profile|accessdate=31 January 2013}}</ref>
In 2014, Sitorus also formed a partnership with [[Roys Poyiadjis]] to create the largest biofuel power plant in Japan. The plant’s 20 year feed-in tariff is valued at $1.5 billion US dollars.<ref>Von Mayer, Wintress. [http://www.altenergymag.com/article/2015/10/two-explosions-a-world-apart-from-disaster-comes-new-power/21596 “Two Explosions a World Apart: From Disaster Comes New Power.”] AltEnergyMag. Oct. 6, 2015</ref>
===Gama Corporation===
Apart from Wilmar, Martua and his elder brother [[Ganda Sitorus]] co-founded [[Gama Corporation]] in 2011, which run property, cement plant and others variety business through subsidiary [[Gama Land]] and [[PT.Cemindo Gemilang|Semen Merah Putih]]. Gama itself refer to its founder name Ganda & Martua (Ga-ma).<ref>https://properti.kompas.com/read/2015/12/21/160000521/Ini.Dia.Aset.Properti.Konglomerat.Ganda-Martua.Sitorus</ref> Gama Corp owns 64 floor [[Gama Tower]] which is located at Rasuna Said - Jakarta, Indonesia. Gama Tower also known as the tallest building in Indonesia.<ref>http://www.skyscrapercenter.com/building/gama-tower/17562 </ref>
[[File:Gama Tower 2018.jpg|thumb|right|Gama Tower 2018|Gama Tower - Jl H.R Rasuna Said - South Jakarta, Indonesia]]
== See also == * [[Energy in Indonesia]]
